T Braakman', 'EG Bakker, LL.M', 'JD Boonstra, MSc', 'mr. A Benhammou', 'mr. ADM Janssen', 'mr. EWL Metzemaekers - Beks', 'mr. I van den Eijnde, LLM', 'mr. J van Poppel', 'mr. K Schriek', 'mr. NP Arzini, LLM', 'mr.dr. E Boomsluiter', 'mr.dr. EW Ros', 'N Cohen', 'prof.mr.dr. AW Schep', 'prof.mr.dr. MMWD Merkx', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']",,"Inhoud

<body>Het schrijven van een scriptie van 12 000-16 000 woorden (10 ects) is een verplicht onderdeel van de masteropleiding Fiscaal recht. Voor de studenten van de variant Directe belastingen geldt dat het onderwerp van hun scriptie betrekking moet hebben op directe belastingen
column2: voor de studenten van de variant Indirecte belastingen zijn dat de Indirecte belastingen.

column1: Het schrijven van de masterscriptie Fiscaal recht is alleen mogelijk met deelname aan het door ons aangeboden scriptietraject. Indien u de wens heeft om in het collegejaar 2018 – 2019 af te studeren, dan dient in ieder geval uw scriptie vóór 26 juni 2018 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider. Indien de scriptie vervolgens wordt goedgekeurd door de tweede lezer, kan de scriptie worden verdedigd tijdens de afstudeerbijeenkomst van eind augustus 2019.&nbsp
Het scriptietraject bestaat uit de volgende&nbsp
<li>Goedkeuring scriptieonderwerp en aanmelding in het scriptievolgsysteem&nbsp
<li>a. Studenten variant Directe belastingen: eerste afspraak met scriptiebegeleider&nbsp
<div>b. Studenten variant Indirecte belastingen: deelname inleidende discussiebijeenkomst&nbsp

Let op: U kunt alleen aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak deelnemen als u aan de verplichte onderdelen 1 t/m 4 hebt voldaan. Dit zal voorafgaande aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak actief worden gecontroleerd.

Het is aan te raden op tijd met de scriptie te beginnen. Uit ervaring is bekend dat vooral de eerste fase van de ontwikkeling van een scriptie (bestaande uit de keuze van het onderwerp, de literatuurverzameling en het inlezen) veel tijd kost. Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat een eventueel in het bachelorwerkstuk behandeld onderwerp niet mag worden 'uitgewerkt' tot een masterscriptie. Het onderwerp van de scriptie dient tijdig aangemeld te worden door middel van het invullen van het 'Aanmeldingsformulier scriptie (Master) Fiscaal Recht'. Na goedkeuring van het onderwerp door de sectie Fiscaal Recht ontvangt u bericht met daarin de naam van de toegewezen scriptiebegeleider. Na goedkeuring ligt het onderwerp vast.&nbsp

Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat niet eerder aan een scriptie kan worden begonnen dan nadat het aanmeldingsformulier is ingeleverd en u bericht heeft ontvangen over het toewijzen van een scriptiebegeleider.&nbsp

Uw scriptie moet binnen twee collegejaren na aanvang van het masterscriptietraject door uw scriptiebegeleider zijn goedgekeurd. Daarna vervalt uw scriptieonderwerp. U dient dan opnieuw het gehele scriptietraject te doorlopen. Dat geldt niet voor het Fiscaal confrontatievak, indien u dat vak al met een voldoende heeft afgesloten. Indien u in het collegejaar 2018/2019 start met uw scriptie dient uw scriptie dus uiterlijk aan het eind van collegejaar 2019/2020 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider.

column9: De student kan op basis van aantoonbare kennis van en inzicht in de wetenschappelijke discipline op een gevorderd niveau een originele bijdrage leveren aan de wetenschappelijke kennis
De student kan zelfstandig op zijn leerproces reflecteren, nieuwe nationale en internationale ontwikkelingen in het fiscale recht signaleren en zich eigen maken

De student kan zelfstandig zijn wetenschappelijk fiscaal juridisch onderzoek, onderzoeksuitkomsten en –voorstellen, zowel schriftelijk als mondeling, presenteren aan een juridische en aan een niet-juridisch onderlegd publiek, en deze bovendien ook beargumenteerd verdedigen.

column1: <body>In een aantal bijeenkomsten van november tot Kerst wordt een technische instructie gegeven voor het schrijven van een bachelor thesis en wordt collectief gewerkt aan eenieders concept voor de thesis. Dat concept dient uiterlijk 1 januari, goedgekeurd door de begeleider, aan de Examencommissie te worden voorgelegd. In minimaal vier bijeenkomsten tussen januari en juni, die in overleg worden geroosterd, worden in kleine groepjes tekstgedeelten van de verschillende theses in wording besproken. Deze bijeenkomsten zijn bedoeld ter ondersteuning van het schrijfproces. Voltijd studenten die in 2019-2020 hun bachelor examen willen afleggen dienen deel te nemen aan de bijeenkomsten. Zonder deelname kan geen bachelor examen worden afgelegd.</body>

<body>Het schrijven van een concept voor de eigen bachelor thesis. Het presenteren en kritisch bespreken van tekstgedeelten uit de eigen thesis. Het constructief-kritisch becommentariëren van tekstgedeelten uit de theses van medestudenten. Het komen tot een eerste volledige versie van de thesis.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93184,2020,Semantic Information Systems,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. F Frasincar'],,"Inhoud

The course starts by introducing the Semantic Web, and ontologies as the cornerstone of the next generation Web. After that, the most relevant Semantic Web data representation languages (XML, RDF, and OWL) and data query/transformation languages (XPath, XQuery, and XSLT) are presented. Some applications of the Semantic Web for building Web Information Systems for finance, marketing, logistics, or information retrieval are also given.

The students will work in teams on several assignments related to the application of the Semantic Web for developing Web Information Systems. The students will write a report describing the proposed solutions.</body>
• Know what the Semantic Web technologies are.
• Understand what a Semantic Web ontology is.
• Be aware of the usefulness of Semantic Web technologies for developing Web Information Systems.
• Be able to develop a Semantic Web ontology.
• Be able to query a Semantic Web ontology.
• Propose Semantic Web solutions for current problems that Web Information Systems face in finance, marketing, logistics, or information retrieval.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93222,2020,Seminar Advanced Corporate Finance: Corporate Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. DL Urban', 'prof.dr. I Dittmann']",,"Inhoud
<body>Corporate governance analyzes two conflicts of interest that arise in the financing of the firm.

• The first is the conflict between shareholders and the firm's management. While shareholders usually want to see a high return on their investment, managers might have a different agenda. They could try to use the firm's funds for their own interests, or to build an empire that is big but unprofitable. We will discuss this problem and its two main solutions: monitoring by a big shareholder and incentive contracts that give the managers a share in the value they created for the firm.

• The second conflict of interest emerges between controlling shareholder and minority shareholders. The controlling shareholder might try to ""tunnel"" money from the firm into her own pocket and thereby to expropriate minority shareholders. Depending on the legal environment, there might be many ways to do this. We will discuss the relevance of this problem and its implications for the ownership structure of the firm and for a firm's ability to obtain outside financing.

Against this background, we will discuss corporate governance laws and codes, the role and composition of the board of directors, executive compensation, the design of financial securities, mergers and acquisitions, and shareholder activism.

This seminar provides you with an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding about what good corporate governance is and why it matters. The course covers some theoretical and legal issues, but its main focus is on empirical research and insights. Therefore, we will analyze, discuss and criticize the methodology used in the empirical research. Hence, this course also aims at building a critical view on any empirical results presented to the student. In two group assignments, you will apply your knowledge and your skills to two different types of tasks.

Active participation in and a strong commitment to this course are a prerequisite. You are expected to present pieces of the literature and to prepare for in-class discussions. You will also present your own results, ask questions, mention doubts and express your ideas in the class discussion. Hence, learning group dynamics is a positive (and important) side effect of this course.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the theory of conflicts of interest within a firm.
• Students have knowledge of different corporate governance standards currently in use and why they matter.
• Students have knowledge of state-of-the-art techniques to resolve problems of endogeneity in empirical settings of corporate governance.
• Students are able to critically discuss in class other authors’ empirical results.
• Students are able to confront alternative empirical findings and evaluate their respective strengths and weaknesses.
• Students are able to design and execute in groups a small scale empirical study.
<body>Reorganization of in-class discussion and the associated grading of oral participation - see course book for details.</body>
Oral participation during seminars counts 50% towards the final grade.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93266,2020,Seminar Advanced Corporate Finance: Empirical Corporate Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. P Verwijmeren'],,Inhoud

This seminar introduces students to the methods and tools used in Empirical Corporate Finance. By reading and discussing seminal papers in Empirical Corporate Finance, students will also get in touch with major results and contributions to the field.

The aim of the course is to provide an understanding of basic econometric methods (panel data and OLS) and performance evaluation techniques (short-run and long-run event studies) used in Empirical Corporate Finance. Furthermore, the course will introduce students to the major financial databases. As such, this course is an excellent preparation for students who intend to write their master thesis in Empirical Corporate Finance. Small case studies will apply academic research to real-world cases.
Assessment is based on presentations, discussions, and a seminar thesis in which a group of students will replicate a well-published empirical paper.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into important research topics in corporate finance
• Students have knowledge of the major empirical techniques used in empirical studies in corporate finance (regression analysis, event study methodology, and panel data analysis).
• Students are able to derive and identify potential thesis topics from the corporate finance papers discussed in class.
• Students are able to independently conduct research in the form of a mini-thesis, in order to understand and answer empirical research questions in a statistically sound way.
<body>New lecturer. Articles have changed to reflect developments and to match with expertise lecturer. Stronger focus on thinking about a research proposal.</body>
Grades are based on presentation(s), participation, and a group research project which requires you to replicate parts of the results of an article using the statistics software STATA.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93223,2020,Seminar Advanced Corporate Finance: Private Equity,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. CS Pfeil', 'dr. JCM Kil', 'prof.dr. JTJ Smit']",,"Inhoud

This seminar aims to provide insights in groundbreaking developments in economic and financial academic research that may have its impact on private equity investment decisions. The recent advancements in game theory, option theory and behavioral economics, have each been honored with Nobel Prices in economics, are the theoretical pillars of this seminar.

Together with financial executives we focus on how to use corporate finance theory to improve actual strategic management practice. The course is structured in two modules. A briefly summary of the modules in the course is as follows:

• The first module ""Private Equity Valuation"" considers the interactions between private equity investors and the acquisitions that they finance. In addition to the traditional valuation methods for targets, we consider dynamic valuation models and bidding contests (e.g., real options and game theory).

• The second module ""Private Equity Performance"" starts by considering behavioral pitfalls which may occur in the acquisition process and how private equity firms are able to shield themselves against these common pitfalls. Also, we consider the recent performance, governance implications and risk in private equity transactions.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into fundamental economic theories in corporate finance (real options, game theory and behavioral theory).
• Students have understanding of application of the theoretical perspectives to practice.
• Students are able to make a thorough valuation of a firm using different valuation methods, drafting an investment proposal (in collaboration with an investment bank).
• Students are able to critically asses different scientific articles and be able to understand the limitations of private equity research.
• Students are able to understand, evaluate and discuss different perspectives towards private equity raised in academic articles.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93230,2020,Seminar Advanced Money, Credit and Banking",Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. NRD Dwarkasing'],,"Inhoud

Money, credit, and banking (MCB) are the tools at our disposal to bring our dreams of the future immediately to the present. This is true for country politicians dreaming of full employment, corporate managers dreaming of innovative growth, and individuals dreaming of a home for their family.

This course discusses the role and impact of MCB by bridging the link between academia and practice. Well-known theories and frameworks on public money and credit (e.g., inflation, monetary policy and central banking,), private money and credit(e.g., financial markets, and the financing of firms) and banking (financial institutions) are presented and evaluated.

How does a modern financial institution or publicly held firm operate and how is it financed? What is the role of central banks, both in the past as well as today, and how does this relate to their mandate? How has financial intermediation changed with technology? And what impact does the role of regulation play in financial markets? All these developments are creating various opportunities -and risks- as we speak, and not understanding this properly can seriously damage your wealth.

At the country level, you will understand the role of MCB in the most important financial crises (the US mortgage crises from 2008, the Euro crisis from 2011, and the current COVID-19 situation that is still evolving), and in the policy responses to these crisis. You will also learn how countries have coped with these crises through unprecedented monetary innovations, and what consequences this has had on the real and financial economy.

At the firm level, you will learn about the role of MCB in the financing of corporations. You will understand the promise and pitfalls of financial market innovations, and bust the myth of the widely held public firm. This will allow you to better understand existing and future financial products and foresee vulnerabilities in financial markets.

The empirical assignment will focus on measuring, quantifying and evaluating Central Bank interventions during times of distress and crises, with a special focus on the COVID-19 situation that we are currently experiencing.
This course is completely changed, with a new lecturer, new topics, and new materials.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93281,2020,Seminar Applied Behavioural Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. JE Rose', 'dr. MFM Hainguerlot', 'dr. SC van der Zee', 'dr. T Wang', 'MAJ van Hulsen, MSc', 'mr. AC Peker, MSc', 'prof.dr. A Baillon']",,"Inhoud

Behavioural economics models systematic deviations from the standard economic model. This seminar will show how to take into account these deviations to improve the predictive power of economic and financial theories. Improving the design and implementation of business strategies and public policies will be dealt with through case studies.

The first part of the course (5 weeks) will consist of guest lectures and case studies in partnership with companies and public organization. The second part of the course (3 weeks) will be dedicated to a research project.
• Identify a problem and analyze its economic and behavioral aspects.
• Develop a solution and give practical recommendations.
The course is fully online this year.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98083,2020,Seminar Auditing,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. J Yu', 'drs. KD Miljoen, RA', 'drs. NA de Vos, RA']",,"Inhoud

<body>This course consists of three parts: (1) Introduction to audit, (2) Audit and ICT, and (3) Auditing Research. ""(1) Introduction to audit"" provides an insight into the history and the basic principles of auditing, and covers the main steps of the audit approach. ""(2) Audit and ICT"" covers various IT related topics. ""(3) Auditing Research"" covers 12 academic papers to understand core research topics such as audit quality.</body>
• Students have knowledge and insight into the history and basic principles of auditing.
• Students have knowledge and insight into the main steps of an audit approach including audit planning, internal control, and control risk.
• Students have knowledge and insight into the use of basic principles of IT in the audit approach.
• Students have knowledge and insight into the use essence of academic research in auditing and assurance.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93105,2020,Seminar Behaviour, Health and Wellbeing",Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['dr. CJ Riumallo Herl', 'dr. M Hendriks', 'prof.dr. C Li']",,"Inhoud

<body>In the seminar Behaviour, Health and Wellbeing students will learn to combine the knowledge and skills obtained in the major courses to analyse and possibly influence behaviour related to health and wellbeing. In particular they will work on two themes: (i) healthy behaviour, (ii) wellbeing
(a) Measuring and analysing behaviour and well-being (e.g., Why do people procrastinate going to the gym?)
(b) Understanding the role of people’s own responsibility (e.g., Should overweight people pay more health insurance premiums?)
(c) Making policy recommendations (e.g., How can we incentivize or nudge healthier behaviour?)
(d) Evaluate the impact of policies (e.g., Can we test whether the incentives work using a field experiment?)
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93272,2020,Seminar Behavioural Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. H Zhu'],,Inhoud

<body>The purpose of this seminar is twofold. First, it covers the most important papers from the behavioral finance literature, with a focus on the recent ""hot topics"" in the field. Second, it gives you the opportunity to engage in academic research. In particular, you will work with data from a Dutch online broker, Binck Bank, to analyze the performance of its clientele, and with aggregate financial and macroeconomic data, to write a short academic paper. Note that the seminar entails both individual and group work.</body>
• Students have knowledge of and insight into state-of-the-art research in behavioral finance.
<li>Students have knowledge of cognitive biases that may affect&nbsp
• Students are able to work with complex cross-sectional, time-series, and panel data sets.
• Students are able to use a wide range of econometric techniques to evaluate and produce behavioral finance research.
• Students are able to write and present a research paper in behavioral finance, with a good understanding of when to define a finding as behavioral.
<body>Since the seminar now belongs to the corporate finance track, topics covered in this seminar will be primarily from the behavrial corporate finance literature.</body>
<body>The grade is based on group case work, discussion participation, and individual presentations.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93300,2020,Seminar Behavioural Investing,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['A Soebhag, MSc', 'prof.dr. G Baltussen']",,"Inhoud

<body>This course aims at improving our understanding of financial markets and asset returns, by applying insights from psychology and other behavioural sciences. Traditionally, the finance paradigm seeks to understand financial decisions by building on optimal acting investors and market forces that correct mispricing
column2: that is, it assumes people behave rational. However, abundant evidence, reveals that this paradigm is too restrictive and in many circumstances gives a poor description of people's behaviour. We (being people) do not always act in the best way possible. In fact, in many decision situations we make mistakes that result in non-optimal behaviour.

column1: Using interactive sessions, the first part of this course will examine various influential behavioural biases and their implications for financial markets and decisions. The second part of the course will consider how behavioural principles can turn into a profit by studying how behavioural biases affect the behaviour of market participants and prices. Finally, the course will learn you how trading strategies can be developed based upon various behavioural pitfalls.</body>
• Students have knowledge of various influential behavioural biases and their implications for financial markets and decisions.
• Students have knowledge of trading strategies can be developed based upon various behavioural pitfalls.
• Students learn how to build trading strategies on behavioral biases and to limit their impact on your investment behavior.
• Students develop a skillset to empirically evaluate various investment strategies.
<body>The course will incorporate the latest practical developments, industry research and academic research papers.&nbsp

Grades are based on presentations, preparation of and active participation in classroom sessions, individual assignments, and/or a group research assignment in which you will apply behavioural principles in investing.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93330,2020,Seminar Case Studies in Applied Econometrics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. A Pick', 'dr. JWN Reuvers']",,"Inhoud

<body>Students work in small groups on a specific theoretical or empirical econometric problem. Topics stem from international macro-, financial, and micro-econometrics. Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. During the end of the term, each group writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the term, in which the research project is presented by members of the group and discussed by a member of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.</body>
• The student learns how to formulate a proper research question with testable hypotheses.
• The student learns to decide upon the correct data and appropriate econometric model to answer the research question.
• The student learns how to do a research project in a team of 4 students.
• The student learns to apply his econometric knowledge to do proper econometric inference.
• The student learns to use estimation output resulting from an econometric analysis to answer the research question and to report his research in a scienfic report and a presentation.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93320,2020,Seminar Case Studies in Business Analytics and Quantitative Marketing,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. A Alfons', 'dr. F Frasincar', 'dr. W Wang', 'prof.dr. D Fok', 'prof.dr. PHBF Franses', 'prof.dr. R Paap', 'prof.dr. SI Birbil']",,"Inhoud

The students are divided in small groups. Each group works on a research question. Usually this research question is put forward by a company. First, the relevant literature is studied. Next, the research question is translated in one or more models. To estimate the parameters of the models, (company) data is used. Much attention will be paid to the selection of the best possible model, given the research question. This model can be any model dealt with in the various courses, but it can also be a model that needs to be developed by the students themselves. The model parameters are estimated, and the model results are interpreted within the light of the research question. The final results will be presented in a scientific report and a presentation.
• Learn how to formulate a research question and how to translate it in an econometric/statistical model.
• Learn how to obtain a well-specified model using techniques from econometrics/statistics/machine learning.
• Learn how to use the outcomes of an analysis to answer the research questions.
• Reporting of academic research in the form of an article.
• Reporting of academic research in the form of a presentation.
<body>No structural changes, new cases are created every year.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93314,2020,Seminar Case Studies in Data Science and Marketing Analytics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. CS Bellet', 'dr. R Karpienko', 'dr. V Avagyan', 'FJL van Maasakkers', 'prof.dr. ACD Donkers']",,"Inhoud

<body>In this seminar, students will solve real world management problems that are typically put forward by companies. These case studies start with the proper formulation and conceptualization of the research question by studying available literature. After acquiring the relevant data, students will determine and apply the appropriate method of analysis. The final deliverable of this seminar will be a report and a presentation- usually at the company headquarters - that provide an answer to the management problem that is well grounded both theoretically and empirically.&nbsp
The specific topics will be driven by the company cases, but they are always connected to generating business relevant insights from data.
What students say about this course:
• Challenge ourselves with a real-life case from a well-known company under demanding conditions.
• The seminar was for us the ultimate test of applying those methods we learned during the previous courses using a real-life dataset.
• The course showed that real life business problems are much more challenging than many of the toy examples we learn in other courses.
<body>Process details have been clarified and guest lectures on relevant skills have been added.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93297,2020,Seminar Cases in Policy Evaluation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. G Moroni', 'dr. IV Ossokina', 'prof.dr. HD Webbink']",,"Inhoud
During the seminar you learn about different ways to conduct policy research, using recent cases in policy evaluation.
• What can we learn about the impact of unemployment policies using quasi-experimental research designs?
• Can we measure the effect of additional funding for schools with a regression discontinuity design?
• How to set up a fiel experiment to analyze the effects of teacher performance pay?
• What does social-cost benefit analysis tell us about the costs and benefits of the Olympic Games?
Students are expected tot discuss and present policy research during the seminar.
Finally, students are expected to do an empirical case study, do research assignments, and write a policy research paper.</body>

• To learn the main techniques in the field of treatment/ policy evaluation: randomized controlled trials, instrumental variables models, regression discontinuity models, difference-in-differences models.
• To understand the underlying assumptions of the main models and the differences with the standard approaches as linear regression and matching models.
• To understand the main techniques of social cost benefit analysis.
• To be able to assess the credibility of policy evaluation by applying the knowledge of the main models and their assumptions.
• To be able to assess the quality of a social cost benefit analysis.
• To be able to present the scientific evidence for a specific policy cases and assess the credility of this evidence.
<body>There will be no changes in the course compared to last year.</body>
• Within two weeks after a possible failure, a rewritten policy paper needs to be handed in.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93309,2020,Seminar Commodity Trading,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. PJPM Versijp'],,Inhoud

The goal of the seminar is to increase your knowledge and understanding of the relevant issues in commodity trading from a Finance perspective. This means that we’ll investigate how commodities can be traded and which factors influences prices of the physical product and derivatives, and how the above relates to investments in assets connected to the commodity trade.
The seminar will benefit from a strong cooperation with Glencore Agricultural Products BV, and will therefore focus on agricultural commodities in particular.
Commodities will be studied from 2 directions: the ‘trade-perspective’ who has to find a way to formulate a view on the market, and act accordingly
column2: and the ‘risk manager's perspective’ where one has to judge if the trades do not combine to excessive risk for the company. As always, these topics will be tackled both through the analysis of empirical data and cases, as well as literature study.</body>

column1: <body>Some optimisation regarding procedures, and limited updating of the contents (e.g. with the negative oil futures price as occurred in April 2020). It is too soon to tell if any corona-related modifications need to be made.</body>
• The final grade is determined based on individual work including discussion contributions (oral and written), presentations, a discussion leadership, and the group assignments with a common grade.
NB: the full 8 weeks will be used, with evaluations after that. Do not plan to be outside the country before the last working of the block, even if the last session has already taken place.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93084,2020,Seminar Competition Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. JJA Kamphorst'],,Inhoud

The seminar 'Competition Policy' mainly deals with theories of competition and public competition policy. Few people would dispute the importance of markets for our (material) welfare. But if these markets are important, then it also matters whether they function well. This is why we study competition theory and policy.

We will consider the nature of market power by firms and the strategic interaction (competition) between them. We will look at which strategies firms may use to be better off themselves and what consequences those have for consumers. And even when such practices would be harmful per se, it remains the question whether it can and should be forbidden. During this course we will gain insight into the factors that the answers to these questions depend on and why that is the case.
In this course we will discuss the four main topics of Competition policy. These are:
• Predation, Entry deterrence and other abusive behavior by firms.
We will analyse these topics using game theoretic tools. Moreover, we will relate our insights to the actual competition laws and policy.</body>
• Reproduce and interpret concepts in Competition Policy.
<li>Discuss the relation and frictions between (1) EC competition law and economic theory
column2: as well as between (2) economic theory and its practical application.

column1: • Apply economic theories regarding competition policy (collusion, predatory behavior, mergers) to analyse, explain and evaluate and advise about the economic policies pursued by companies, governments and institutions.
• Present scientific papers on Industrial Organization(explain model, results and why those results follow from the model), and use such papers when evaluating competition cases.
Presentations will be online and distributed (and watched) before the seminar. That leaves more time for discussion and questions during the seminar meetings.
The retake will replace the examination only. In order to receive a sufficient grade a minimum grade of a 5,0 on the examination is required.
Grades for paper and other assignments remain valid until the end of the academic year.
NB: Application to this seminar implies obligatory attendance in case of admission!&nbsp
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93236,2020,Seminar Consumer Channel Dynamics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr.ir. BGC Dellaert'],,Inhoud

<body>Increasingly firms and consumers work closely together in the value creation process. For example, more and more firms allow customers to customize products to their own taste (e.g., NikeID). Other firms rely heavily on consumers to provide information and also actual services to other consumers (e.g., Uber, Airbnb). To be successful, these new business models typically use many different (digital) marketing channels and strongly integrate information technology in their interactions with consumers. This course analyzes how best to support individual consumers across different channel functions, and how to find ways to activate consumers to become value creators in their own right. To better understand recent trends, the course also activates students to review current examples of firms' usage of information technology to support consumer value creation.</body>

• Students will develop a better understanding of how firms and consumers interact to create greater consumer value. In particular, students learn to define and analyze different stages in the value creation process in which consumer-firm interactions take place.
<li>Students learn how to analyze consumer decisions in the different&nbsp
column2: consumer-firm interaction stages. The course focuses on the following stages: consumer information search and choice, consumer purchase decisions, consumer product use, and consumer product evaluations.

column1: • Students practice how to analyze real-world innovative marketing approaches using academic research on consumer-firm interactions and consumer enhancement.
• Students practice creatively developing new marketing value creation ideas based on richer consumer-firm interactions and consumer enhancement. They also practice critically assessing these ideas.
Based on student feedback, an exam was introduced to promote more close studying of the articles in the course.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93070,2020,Seminar Corporate Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. NRD Dwarkasing', 'dr. VV Volosovych']",,"Inhoud

<body>In this seminar we discuss the key topics in corporate finance, with particular attention to practical applications. The subjects include investment and capital structure decisions by businesses. During the seminar, students will present and discuss academic papers and case studies, including a company valuation where we try to arrange a guest lecture of a valuation expert or company CEO/CFO. The literature mainly consists of articles from the reputable academic journals, as well as chapters from the leading practitioners books and internationally acclaimed finance textbooks. Students are expected to solve the cases and actively study the assigned literature, that is, read and present the articles/chapters, write discussion points related to the readings, and actively participate in group discussions.</body>
• Learning more advanced techniques and theories regarding the valuation of companies.
• Having first-hand practical experience with valuing a company and/or a investment project.
• Learning of how the investment and capital structure decisions are made by corporations.
• Understanding the difference between price and the fundamental value.
• Learning to work individually on mastering the class material and in group on a valuation case.
The final grade is determined based on discussion contributions (oral and written), a presentation, discussion leadership. and the group work on a case.
Attendance of all sessions is required.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93602,2020,Seminar Corporate Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. MHR Erkens'],,Inhoud
Corporate governance analyzes two conflicts of interest that arise in the financing of the firm.

The first is the conflict between shareholders and the firm's management. While shareholders usually want to see a high return on their investment, managers might have a different agenda. They could try to use the firm's funds for their own interests, or to build an empire that is big but unprofitable. We will discuss this problem and its two main solutions: monitoring by a big shareholder and incentive contracts that give the managers a share in the value they created for the firm.

The second conflict of interest emerges between controlling shareholder and minority shareholders. The controlling shareholder might try to tunnel money from the firm into her own pocket and thereby to expropriate minority shareholders. Depending on the legal environment, there might be many ways to do this. We will discuss the relevance of this problem and its implications for the ownership structure of the firm and for a firm's ability to obtain outside financing.

Against this background, we will discuss corporate governance laws and codes, the role and composition of the board of directors, executive compensation, the design of financial securities, mergers and acquisitions, and shareholder activism.

This seminar provides you with an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding about what good corporate governance is and why it matters. The course covers some theoretical and legal issues, but its main focus is on empirical research and insights. Therefore, we will analyze, discuss and criticize the methodology used in the empirical research. Hence, this course also aims at building a critical view on any empirical results presented to the student.&nbsp

Active participation in and a strong commitment to this course are a prerequisite. You are expected to present pieces of the literature and to prepare for in-class discussions. You will also present your own results, ask questions, mention doubts and express your ideas in the class discussion. Hence, learning group dynamics is a positive (and important) side effect of this course.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93271,2020,Seminar Customer Intelligence and CRM,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. A Scekic'],,Inhoud
<body>Marketing focus has been shifting from the product to the individual customer as the unit level of analysis. Managers are increasingly concerned with the long term profitability of customers
column2: and with their ability to collect (and analyze) consumer data and manage both the value consumers provide to the firm and the value a firm can provide to the consumers. That is why Customer Intelligence and Customer Relationship Management (CRM) have become essential parts of the decision making process for successful firms.

column1: This course will teach you how to gather data about your consumers, and how to make sense of it in order to make decisions within the organization. The course will show you the benefits of using a systematic and analytical approach to marketing decision making, and will allow you to build your skills and confidence in undertaking such analyses and decision making in the context of CRM. A ""consumer-focused"" approach will enable you to acquire research techniques that provide more detailed insights into the behavior of your customers.
The course is designed for students who have extensive background in or understanding of marketing research and marketing principles.
• Teach students how to identify a marketing problem and obtain reliable information to better understand the customer.
• Provide students with an understanding of the role that analytical techniques play in enhancing marketing decision making in modern enterprises.
• Provide students with the software tools that will enable them to apply the methods taught in the course to real marketing problems.
• Improve students' skills in viewing marketing processes and relationships systematically and analytically.
<body>After this course the students should be able to:
• Identify the right context of the real life marketing problem where the data collection methods and models discussed in class can be applied.
• Create effective measurement instruments aimed at gathering data about their consumers.
• Explain the construction of key statistical models used to describe consumer behavior.
• Use statistical software to conduct the analyses discussed in class.
• Communicate the results to the general audience in an intuitive and practically relevant way.

• This course now includes a “customer intelligence” part: that is, sessions on how to create effective measurement tools (such as focus groups, surveys, or experiments) in order to gather reliable data on the consumers and make marketing decisions.
• As the content of some sessions has changed, the assignments have also changed, to include a discussion and practical exercises on the “customer intelligence” methods introduced in the class.
<body>A sufficient grade for the written exam and the assignments is required to pass the course.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93597,2020,Seminar Data Analytics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. FM Elfers', 'dr. J Bae', 'dr. J Pierk', 'dr. Y Gan']",,"Inhoud

The general objective of this course is to acquire methodological and analytical skills to analyze large datasets.. The analysis of big dataset produces information that can be effectively used to improve decision-making and business outcomes.
<body>Students should be able to communicate with data specialists and understand the strength and limits of data analysis in the field&nbsp
Set-up: All lecturers are held online via Zoom and students are requested to turn their camera on during the entire lecture.
Assessment: 50% based on group assignments and 50% based on a final closed book exam.</body>

In this seminar several data science/machine learning methods are treated sequentially. First, students acquire the basics behind various machine learning techniques after which they deepen their knowledge and understanding of the methods by implementing and applying the methods to real data.
We discuss and apply several ""state-of-the-art"" machine learning methods. &nbsp
column2: Students are asked to critically assess, present and discuss the material. Reviewing state-of-the art methods and their application in business settings will help students to assess whether (and how) data can be used to help answer real world business problems.&nbsp

column1: What students say about the course:
Exhaustive coverage of the main state-of-the-art machine learning techniques, from students to students learning approach""
“The best way to learn something, is by trying to explain it to others. You are forced to know every part and detail of the subject.”

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93264,2020,Seminar Developing and Marketing New Products,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. S Stremersch', 'prof.dr. V Landsman Schwartz - Schwartz']",,"Inhoud

In modern markets, much of a firm’s growth depends on its ability to develop and market new products. In this course, we start with discussing value creation, the market dynamics of innovations, and industry evolution through innovation.
We build on your general knowledge in the marketing area and let you apply it via the extensive discussion of case studies and through other (case-based) assignments.</body>
• Students will understand the different stages of the new product development process, from opportunity identification until product launch.
• Students will identify and understand recent developments in innovation and marketing and the possibilities to involve consumers in the process.
• Students will have deepened their prior marketing knowledge within the area of innovation-related marketing.
• Students will master quantitative tools to study new markets and new products through the analysis of innovative company cases and recent findings from the academic literature in the field.
• Students will develop skills to build an innovative mindset.
• Students will be trained to apply their acquired theoretical knowledge to real-world business problems.
<body>One business case was changed based on students feedback.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93296,2020,Seminar Economic Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. KFJ Spiritus', 'prof.dr. DS Schindler']",,"Inhoud

<body>The definitive decision on the main topic(s) will be made before the start of the course. During the course, students will get an in-depth theoretical and empirical background into the economics of main topics of the course.&nbsp

Guest lecturers with strong expertise in the main topics and policy makers will be invited. Students are expected to prepare lectures well. During the lectures students will present articles from a list of required reading to the whole class. Active student participation in the course will be rewarded.

During this course, each student will be writing a policy paper on an important aspect of the main topic(s) of this course. Students will provide a theoretically sound and empirically founded policy advice to solve the policy problem under consideration. Since policy questions will generally be very broad, different students will analyze different sub-questions in their papers.&nbsp
The lecturers provide assistance with writing the papers. Students need to defend their analysis in a class presentation.</body>
• To require in-depth knowledge about one of the most pressing policy issues of our time, such as the eurocrisis, global warming, inequality, taxation of multinationals or the corona-crisis.
• To understand the economics of a policy question from theoretical literature.
• To judge the relevance of theoretical arguments using empirical evidence.
• To weigh different theoretical arguments based on their empirical validity.
• To formulate a policy advice based on sound economic reasoning, backed up by solid empirical evidence.
• To defend the analysis of a policy question in a presentation.
• To write an economic policy advice that contains i) theoretical analysis, ii) empirical evidence of theoretical arguments iii) weighing various arguments iv) formulating a policy recommendation.
<body>The set-up of the seminar remains the same, the topic will be updated and focused on the Covid19 crisis, however. Teachers also have changed as Kevin Spiritus replaces Bas Jacobs.</body>
<body>The assessment of a student will be based on
• the policy paper (groups of four students) and the presentation of it (60%),
• and the oral examination on the literature discussed in the course (20%).

Students are required to participate actively by presenting and discussing academic articles and do assignments. If there are more than 24 students enrolled in this seminar, students will be divided into classes of maximum 24 students. https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93293,2020,Seminar Empirics of Trade and Development,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. EM Bosker'],,Inhoud
This course provides students with an overview of the latest empirical work in the fields of international trade and economic development.
Students will become acquainted with the most recent empirical methods used to uncover the determinants of international trade flows, and (long-run) economic development.

The aim is to give students the basic tools to read and understand the latest empirical work that claims to uncover the role of international trade or globalization in general on countries' or regions' overall level economic development, as well as the role of trade as a driver of income inequality. Upon finishing this course students are able to critically evaluate these studies and judge their validity.

The seminar starts with a brief crash course on the most recent econometric methods used to identify the important factors determining trade and development patterns around the globe. Subsequently, we will critically discuss some of the most influential recent empirical contributions in the fields of international trade and economic development.&nbsp

• This course provides the students with the basic tools to read and understand the latest empirical work that claims to uncover one or more important factors determining countries’ participation in world trade, or their overall level of economic development.
<li>Upon the completion of this course, students will be able to critically evaluate modern empirical studies&nbsp
column2: n the fields of international and development economics and judge their validity.

column1: • This course provides students with a thorough understanding of the issues faced by any empirical researcher that aims to establish causal effects using non-experimental data.
• A brief crash course/introduction is given in the use of the statistical package STATA.
<body>The course will be fully online this year. the setup will mostly be unchanged - the reading list of papers will differ with more recent, different papers added to the list.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93263,2020,Seminar Finance for Sustainability,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. R Huisman', 'VC Stet, MSc']",,"Inhoud
<body>In this seminar students apply financial economics to understand how we improve the sustainability of our society.&nbsp
The students work individually and in groups on cases about different topics.&nbsp

Firstly, we'll focus on power from sustainable sources such as wind and solar. The volumes produced by renewable energy sources is variable and intermittent. As power is not (yet) storable on a large scale, variation in volume from renewable energy sources leads to increased volatility in power prices. This should increase the value of real options such as storage facilities and flexible consumption. The students will study power prices and research the potential of those real options. In addition, we'll study emission rights, such as those from the EU ETS, to see what (expected) price levels are needed to reach our sustainability targets.

Secondly, we'll focus on the financing of investments needed for sustainabilty. Innovation and leadership is needed for innovation to stimulate sustainability, but it is yet unclear to what extend this influences investors's appetite for return. The students research different financing solutions such as crowd funding, to understand whether these solutions are consistent with financial economic theory and whether they are sufficient to improve sustainability.
<body>After this seminar participating students may expect to understand:
<li>how volumes from renewable energy sources influence power prices in wholesale markets
<li>how the EU ETS system works and how the prices of emission right enhance sustainability
<li>what crowd funding is and whether crowd funding attracts investors with risk / return appetite as we'd expect from investors
<li>how financial economics theory can be applied to improve sustainability
<li>have gained practive in doing academical and practical research
<li>how to structure a research project starting from an abstract research question
<body>The focus is on the inclusion of renewable energy in the power market.</body>
<body>The grade for the course is the weighted average of an individual paper (50%), and a group paper (50%).</body>

M Grith', 'dr. MD Zaharieva', 'dr. O Kleen', 'dr. R Lange', 'dr. SOR Lonn', 'prof.dr. DJC van Dijk']",,"Inhoud

Students work in teams of 4 on specific (theoretical or empirical) financial econometric research projects, which are supplied by firms in the financial industry (including asset managers, hedge funds, insurance companies, and pension funds). Examples include problems in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing.

Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. Each group writes a report about its research.&nbsp
column2: A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the course term, in which the research project is presented by a member of the group and discussed by a member of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.</body>

column1: • Learn how to formulate a proper research question with testable hypotheses.
• Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques and necessary data to answer the research question.
• Learn how to use the outcomes of an econometric analysis to answer the research questions.
• Learn to report about the research project in the form of a (scientific) report and a presentation.
• Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
No fundamental changes compared to previous years.
Given the current COVID-19 related restrictions, the meetings with the project supervisors will probably take place online, instead of at the firms' offices or on-campus.</body>
This course is only accessible for students enrolled in the Master programme in Econometrics and Management Science.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93317,2020,Seminar Fintech Strategy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. S van Bekkum', 'RY de Jong']",,"Inhoud

<body>The program starts with an overview in the FinTech industry from both academic and industrial perspectives, followed by a recent topic in FinTech (distributed ledger technology) and the money-like features of coins and tokens. These topics are treated in a way to teach students developing an analytical mindset and evaluating business strategies. Activities in this seminar involves paper presentation, group discussion, case studies, and empirical data analysis. Note that the seminar entails both individual and group work.</body>

<body>The purpose of this seminar is to prepare students with the knowledge, skills, and mindset to advise on FinTech subjects. The program emphasizes both the academic understanding and the applications of recent financial innovations.&nbsp
The seminar of last year has been split in two separate seminars:
Topics in Fintech (block 2) that discusses the recent academic insights, and Fintech Strategy (block 3) in which you will work through cases to strategically evaluate recent Fintech developments.
This makes it possible to go more in-depth, and and decreases the time pressure (which was a bit too high last year).</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93292,2020,Seminar Firms in International Trade,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. A Erbahar'],,Inhoud

<body>Following the most recent trends in empirical research, this seminar will take a firm-level approach to the study of international trade. To have a firm grasp in understanding the empirics, we will start off with the “new” trade theory of international trade, its extension with heterogeneous firms, and the related gravity model of trade. We will then focus on the empirical research on heterogeneous firms and trade by studying and discussing frontier academic papers. The topics covered will include: self-selection into exporting, learning by exporting, multi-product firms, intermediaries in trade, and most importantly, the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms.</body>

<body>The purpose of this seminar is to provide students with an understanding of the role of firms in international trade. By completing this course, students will be able to answer questions such as: Why only a few firms export? How are they different than other firms? How do multi-product firms engage in international trade? What is the role of intermediaries in facilitating trade? What is the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms? Upon the completion of this course, the students will be able to critically evaluate empirical research, especially in identifying causal effects using micro-data to answer policy-relevant questions.</body>
The course has been updated according to the recent developments in the international trade field.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93935,2020,Seminar Four Centuries of Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. PAE Koudijs'],,Inhoud

In this seminar, we will explore Finance’s fascinating history to generate valuable insights for today’s world. The seminar is organized around four themes (1) securities markets, with special emphasis on how information is processed by financial markets, (2) limited liability, with special emphasis on entrepreneurship and banking, (3) banking and financial crises, with special emphasis on banking regulation and the real effects of crises, and (4) politics and finance, with special emphasis on the interaction between finance and people’s political attitudes. This seminar is relevant for all students who are interested in why today’s financial system looks the way it does, what lessons we can draw from past failures and successes, and the implications this has for how we should organize financial markets and institutions today. Tasks include the presentation and discussion of scientific papers. For the final (group) assignment, students will write a policy brief based on historical research. Alternatively, students will get the opportunity to develop a thesis proposal.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the important role financial markets play in processing information, and how that information shapes real economic decisions.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: limited liability, and the role this plays in risk-taking decisions
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the central role of banks and other financial institutions, the way they operate, and the inherent risks they pose.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: how politics and finance can interact to have positive or negative impact on society
• Students are able to: read, interpret and evaluate academic work.
• Students are able to: translate academic findings into policy relevant insights
• Students are able to: write a concise and effective policy brief
• Students are able to: identify potential thesis topics from the topics discussed in class.
<body>First year Peter Koudijs teach this seminar.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93278,2020,Seminar Global Brand Strategy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['M Gregori, MSc', 'prof.dr. MG de Jong']",,"Inhoud

The course examines specific issues involved in developing and executing brand strategy on an international (pan-regional or global) scale as opposed to a domestic scale. The course is intended to provide a thorough understanding of global brand strategies, including (i) pitfalls and challenges of entering other countries, (ii) ways to design effective global brand strategies, (iii) key issues in the implementation of global brand strategies.

Most traditional market boundaries have disappeared. Successful firms in sectors as diverse as consumer packaged goods, consumer durables, industrial goods, and services have discovered that traditional rules of competition - such as focusing only on the competitive interplay in each country separately - have changed dramatically in today's globalized markets. New strategies are determining who are the winners and the losers. Firms that respond proactively to the challenges of a globalized world outperform firms who are unable to adequately respond to a changed world. Firms cannot ignore this trend to globalization. Even if they decide not to be involved in the global or pan-regional (ASEAN, EU, Mercosur, NAFTA, etc.) marketplace, companies still face increased competition in their home markets because of nimble foreign competitors reaping the benefits of global strategies.

The course will help you achieve your career goals as virtually all of you will work in or with companies that are active in the international marketplace as well as domestic companies that face international competitors.

A number of cases will be used, together with a computer-based international marketing simulation game, CountryManager. The simulation will entail selecting a new international market for entry, establishing a brand presence in that market, and expanding into additional foreign markets.</body>
• Knowledge of factors and criteria that determine foreign market attractiveness.
• Knowledge of how to design and implement effective global marketing strategies.
• Developing a marketing plan for foreign market development.
• Managing international expansion activities as a country manager in a real-world setting (simulation game).

column3: performance at national and regional level.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93304,2020,Seminar Institutional Asset Management,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. OW Steenbeek'],,Inhoud

This seminar looks into the business of institutional asset managers. In particular, you will learn about pension funds that manage billions of dollars in assets and affect the lives of many millions of retirees, endowment funds that sustain major educational institutions, and sovereign wealth funds that benefit a whole nation. The goal of this course is to develop a broad perspective on the asset management business.

An array of different developments has been affecting the international asset management industry in recent years. In particular, the strong volatility in equity markets, interest rates falling to unprecedented low and even negative levels, extreme moves in oil prices and currencies, the availability of new asset classes and the ongoing aging of populations in many countries. Meanwhile, the amount of assets managed professionally has multiplied in the last decade and the institutions have become a major player in international capital flows.

The seminar is structured around three main topics. First, the course starts with analyzing the largest category of institutional investors based on assets under management, defined benefit and defined contribution pension funds. We will also study endowment funds and sovereign wealth funds, and compare the asset and liabilities of these institutional investors.

Second, the seminar will focus on the asset allocation policy implemented by institutional investors. We will answer two key questions. How do institutions decide on the level of capital to allocate to individual asset classes? How to implement the asset allocation? The seminar will discuss in detail the issues of diversification, portfolio optimization, trading costs, passive and active strategies. We will discuss not only traditional investments in equity and fixed income, but also investments in alternative assets, like private equity, hedge funds and real estate. The students will also work on a quantitative assignment that analyzes the added value of alternative assets for the current portfolio of a pension fund.

Third, the seminar will cover in-depth the governance and organizational complexities surrounding institutional investors. This part of the course will discuss the fiduciary responsibilities of institutional investors and study the role of socially responsible investing and institutional shareholder activism. An important question is whether investing in this type of funds has (positive or negative) consequences for institutional investors because of the inherent restriction of the universe of stocks.

We will also work on a case study of All Pensions Group (APG), the largest Dutch institutional asset manager. In this assignment, the students benefit from working under the supervision of Prof.dr. O.W. Steenbeek, who is Managing Director of Strategic Portfolio Advice APG, in addition to his affiliation with Erasmus University.

This seminar will be of great interest to students aiming for a career in the asset management business. A fundamental understanding of the issues in institutional portfolio management will also be beneficial for students focused on other areas of financial economics such as investment banking, corporate finance, governance, accounting, insurance and household finance. In addition, students will learn how to better manage their future personal wealth. To succeed in finance industry, you need to master the quantitative skills of a portfolio manager. To be a leader in this field, you also need a thorough knowledge of how markets and organizations function across countries.</body>
• The goal of this seminar is to get a better understanding of the way institutional asset managers invest large pools of financial assets.
• Insights in the role of alternative asset classes in a portfolio, such as hedge funds, private equity and commodities.
• Insights in the difference and between active and passive investment strategies and the implications for asset management organization.
• Insights in the way a specific asset manager works by doing a case study and visiting the company.
• Students will learn how to work in groups, participate in a discussion, critically read academic articles, present to an audience.
Corona obviously forces us to teach this class online. As a consequence, the assignments and the grading weights will be adjusted.
However, the core of this seminar will be the same as previous years, as we will study current academic literature which will be presented and discussed, do individual and group assignments.
n addition, there will be a large number of guest lectures for which discussion questions will have to be prepared.
Check Canvas for the latest updates.</body>
The main elements for which you receive a grade are: group assignments (50%), presentation (15%), participation (15%), individual assignment (10%) and a small in-class exam (10%) at the end.

This course aims at providing exposure to relevant topics on international financial markets. Five main topics are covered: (1) sovereign default models, (2) international transmission of shocks, (4) the international transmission of monetary policy, (4) international risk sharing and the home bias puzzle, and (5) the effect of international capital flows on economic activity. We will cover both theories and empirical studies. This is a master course appropriate for students with previous knowledge on macroeconomic theory and/or econometrics and/or finance. The evaluation includes participation and presentations in class, homework and an essay.
• Students have knowledge of stylized facts regarding international capital flows.
• Students have knowledge of models of international risk sharing, home biases, and sovereign default.
• Students have knowledge of the international transmission of shocks through financial markets.
• Students are able to interpret findings in academic papers.
Instead of one problem set with 5 exercises, we split the problem set into two so that the workload is more spread across the term.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93245,2020,Seminar Regional and Transport Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['G Mingardo', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort']",,"Inhoud

<body>Cities and regions are going through a constant process of economic, social and spatial change. This applies to the most successful global cities but also to those cities that had to go through (or are still going through) a process of economic restructuring because their dominant industries collapsed. This continuous economic, social, and spatial development of cities can strengthen its competitive position but for cities struggling to reinvent their economies, it can be (and possibly still is) a painful process. Additionally, urban areas, companies and citizens increasingly face problems in terms of accessibility and mobility. Congestion, pollution and social exclusion are only some of the major challenges that decision makers have to address. And they have to do this in a fast-changing world
column2: in recent years new forms of mobility (sharing-, electric-, micro-, floating-mobility) have developed at a fast pace. Finally, the recent COVID-19 crisis will most probably influence the way we travel for a while.

column1: Hence, the economic and transport development of cities and regions are topics that are high on the agenda of companies, policymakers, practitioners and academics.

In this seminar, the objective is to develop the ability to give strategic advice to stakeholders in order to increase their competitiveness. Students learn to use different research methods (i.e. data analysis, case study, surveys etc.) in order to come up with intelligent solutions to the most common urban and transport problems. These skills can be used by students when conducting research for their master thesis.

The seminar includes guest speakers’ presentations and/or field visits. It is an intensive course that combines interactive group discussions, the writing of weekly individual essays, (field) assignments as well as empirical group work and assignments.
• To deepen the knowledge on specific regional and transport problems by advanced scientific readings.
• To develop the ability to apply research and methodological tools to analyse contemporary regional and transport challenges.
• To develop accurate and sound economic strategic advice for stakeholders.
Every year the number and types of journal articles that are used change according to the exact content of the program.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93224,2020,Seminar Risk Management,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. T Eisert', 'prof.dr. S Gryglewicz']",,"Inhoud

<body>The globalization of business paired with rapid technological changes, increased volatility in the financial markets, and extraordinary monetary policy measures has changed the risk profiles of many companies and banks dramatically. At the same time, derivative markets have grown accordingly and the routes to managing market and credit risks have expanded. As a result, many firms have embraced the concept of risk management. However, applying derivatives for risk management ('financial engineering') requires a deep understanding of their characteristics, their pricing and last but not least of the markets on which they are traded. In addition, because of the interplay of various risks at the aggregated firm level, risks should be analyzed and managed in a coherent and consolidated way. This seminar is devoted to the analysis and management of risks and complements the course FEM11023 - Financial Risk Management. The seminar covers a wide range of derivative contracts, ranging from plain vanilla (forwards, futures, swaps and options) to more exotic (exotic options, weather and insurance derivatives). It explains arbitrage arguments, trading strategies, the use of binomial trees, Black &amp
column3: : Scholes valuation, volatility smiles, and the ' Greeks'. You will learn about derivatives markets and how derivative instruments can be used for risk management. Moreover, you will learn how changes in monetary policy and the macroeconomic environment affect the business models of financial institutions. By means of group assignments, various practical and theoretical issues of derivatives, risk analysis, integrated risk management, and the changing role of banks for the real economy are explored in depth.

column1: The body of knowledge you gain from actively participating in this seminar is important:
• From the perspective of a corporate treasurer who is interested in hedging his exposure to market risk factors
• From the perspective of a fund manager who wants to change the nature of his/her exposure to financial markets and

• From the perspective of a financial institution that trades derivatives and is faced with an increasingly complex regulatory environment, extraordinary monetary policy measures, and the rise of fintech companies
• Students have understanding of hedging strategies using derivatives.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the risk management of banks.
• Students are able to value futures and options using various methods.
• Students are able to use GARCH models to measure and manage risk and to price derivatives.
• Students have knowledge of the effect of monetary policy on economic decisions by banks.
The final grade is determined based on individual work including discussion contributions (oral and written), presentations, a discussion leadership, and the group assignments with a common grade.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93235,2020,Seminar Strategic Marketing,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. NM Almeida Camacho', 'P Gorji']",,"Inhoud

Marketing has become an important integral part of today's business activities. However, the process through which strategic marketing decisions should be taken is not always clear. In particular, in many firms there is a tension between short-term (tactical) decisions aimed at improving financial returns versus long-term (strategic) decisions aimed at increasing the firm value in the long term. Moreover, marketers are increasingly required to make evidence-based decisions and to be able to integrate their decisions with the overall firm strategy (i.e. to deliberate on the financial and operational consequences of marketing decisions). All these issues make strategic marketing a top concern for firms and a fascinating topic. In this seminar we discuss the important role of strategic marketing and its impact on the long term value of a firm.

We will build upon theoretical insights obtained from academic research with the more practical marketing decision environment (e.g. the role of marketing intelligence in strategic decisions). Students will also be exposed to stressful decision-making situations which require deep collaboration and teamwork and sharp usage of marketing intelligence and strategizing skills, in line with the situations students will face as professional marketers. These goals will be achived by playing an exciting and sophisticated marketing strategy simulation game (StratSim) and working on several assignments related to strategic decisions taken in this simulated environment.

Furthermore, we will also pay attention to the development of soft skills as well as analytical marketing and presentation/reporting skills. Specifically, during the marketing strategy simulation game, students will be exposed to the need to interpret output from marketing analyses and use their marketing knowledge to make decisions that will have market and financial consequences for their simulated firms. In the end, the students, role-playing as company managers, will need to present the rationale and lessons from their strategic decisions to a board of shareholders (the rest of the class).</body>
• Learn how to do evidence-based strategic marketing decisions
• Learn classic and state-of-the-art strategic marketing theories
• Discuss how to apply theory to practice (skills you can use as a strategic marketer)
• Learn how to use marketing research tools and customer and market insights
- We have online sessions for the lectures and online coaching sessions for StratSim.
- Our two guest lectures (DHL and T-Mobile) are shorter because they are online.
- Post-mortem session is going to be hybrid.</body>

The content of the seminar is fourfold. Two group assignments:
1. Solving a business case on a strategy issue using relevant insights from the academic literature and available data to the best extent.

2. Collecting and summarizing research papers to give an overview of relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy Providing a critical assessment of the literature to identify a relevant research question for further research.
3. Presenting a research paper in class to give an insight in relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy. Answering questions from fellow students and moderating a class discussion.
4. Writing a summary on each of the research questions discussed in class with critical assessment of the presented papers.
1. Can successful management practices be transferred across countries and firms?
2. What is the impact of top managers on the performance of firms?
3. Can firms acquire new technology by hiring workers?
4. What is the effect of entry regulation on economic performance?
5. Why are firms using other firms to produce their output?</body>
• Read and understand state-of-the-art economic literature on strategy, managerial economics and firm entry and exit.
• Summarize and communicate insights from scientific papers on industrial dynamics and strategy in a class presentation.
• Search and analyse firm data in a group project to solve a business case related to entry strategy.
• Write an informed opinion on current topics in industrial dynamics and strategy research based on relevant literature.
• Conduct an in-depth literature review and define a relevant research question on a specialized topic in industrial dynamics and strategy.
