https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93289,2020,Seminar Supply Chain Management and Optimisation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr.ir. R Dekker'],,Inhoud

<body>This seminar gives an overview of important developments in supply chains, and the management thereof. It gives a tool-box in terms of research skills (Excel skills and finding data) and methods in order to be able to analyze and optimize supply chains, focusing on costs as well as value added. We focus on a case for importing white goods from China to Europe. The case serves to get hands-on experience in the considerations for choosing between different transport modes (what to ship and what to truck, cost structures, selection of distribution network, port choices and locations of distribution centers. Finally we also evaluate environmental issues relating to supply chains. The required theory will be given in five courses at the start of the seminar.</body>
• To understand the effect of various supply chain drivers and development.
• To be able to analyse a supply chain according to various characteristics.
• To be able to apply simplified supply chain design and transport chain models.
• To develop the research skills and methods necessary to analyze and optimize supply chains.
• To develop computer skills (spreadsheets) to do supply chain calculations and visualising.
• To present results in a clear and convincing way.
As the course on Quantitative Logistics was cancelled, we will now briefly summarise the theory needed in the first few lectures.
The case itself will be slightly changed. The part on Reverse Logistics will be removed. It might come back in the course on Sustainable Logistics.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93085,2020,Seminar The Economics of Exchange Rates,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. Y Chen'],,Inhoud

This course concentrates on exchange-rate theory and policy. The seminar has five parts. It begins with a review of important concepts related to foreign exchange markets. This is followed by a discussion of different models of exchange rate determination and their policy implications. In the third part, we will discuss exchange market efficiency and the forecasting of exchange rates. The fourth part looks at what constitutes an optimal currency area and implications for the euro area. In the last part of the seminar, we will study the currency crises. Topics and emphasis may differ per semester, depending on the actuality.
• Master the various models of exchange rates and establish their economic policy relevance.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93175,2020,Seminar in Financial Econometrics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['B Van Os, MSc', 'dr. M Zhelonkin', 'J Klooster', 'JA Oorschot', 'KP de Wit, MSc', 'PA Opschoor', 'prof.dr. C Zhou', 'prof.dr. RL Lumsdaine', 'SHLCG Vermeulen', 'T van der Zwan, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Students work in teams of 4 on specific (theoretical or empirical) financial econometric research projects. Examples include problems in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing.

Each team has its own supervisor. Teams meet with their supervisor on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. Each team writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the course term, in which the research project is presented by a member of the team and discussed by a member of another team, followed by a plenary discussion.
Learn how to formulate a proper research question.
Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques to answer the research question.
Learn how to apply quantitative models to data.
Learn how to translate model results to answers to research questions.
Learn to report about the research project in the form of a (scientific) report and a presentation.
Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
No fundamental changes compared to previous years.
Given the current COVID-19 related restrictions concerning on-campus education, the weekly progress meetings with the project supervisor will probably take place online.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93307,2020,Seminar in Firm Location Strategy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. B Karreman', 'dr. Z Wang', 'prof.dr. MJ Burger']",,"Inhoud

<body>The choice of location has a profound influence on firm performance in terms of productivity, profit, and innovation. For example, the availability of a large pool of skilled labor or access to an excellent transport infrastructure may considerably enhance a firm's productivity. This makes multinationals very selective in choosing locations (for offices, distribution centers, production, etc.). There are many types of foreign direct investments, and each type has different requirements in terms of location. Due to a globalizing world, the choice set of multinationals becomes larger, which makes the investment decision increasingly challenging. Given the high commercial stakes, location choices are prominent in the strategy of multinationals. Investment decisions are also a game with several competing local and regional governments. Politicians and policy makers are willing to offer facilities in terms of tax cuts, subsidies, and public amenities as foreign direct investments are thought to boost the economic performance of a region. The aim of this seminar is to gain understanding about the location decisions of multinationals and to what extent these decisions are influenced by local and regional governments. During the first half of the course, students are expected to present and discuss recent articles related to foreign direct investments by multinationals. In the second half of the course, students have to conduct an empirical study in which they combine econometric techniques with theories on multinational strategy and foreign direct investment.</body>
<li>Learning about the environment in which firms operate
column2: including location, network and industry influences. In particular, we focus on the location choice of multinational firms.

column1: • Think and act in an academic way on the interface of economics, international business and geography.
• Communicate on theories and empirical research on multinational corporations, foreign direct investment and economic development.
• Conduct an empirical study on the location choice of firms using econometric techniques.

This course will prepare you toward gaining research experience before you begin your independent research project for thesis. The participants in the course are divided into small groups and conduct research related assignments (e.g., data analysis, literature review, etc.). Participants also work on individual assignment(s).

The topics for research include strategic firm behavior and strategic behavior by employees and entrepreneurs. Broad areas include among others competitive strategy, innovation strategy, export strategy and growth strategy.</body>
• How to formulate a research question that is simple, novel, and consequential.
• To evaluate the impact of public policies and firm strategies on performance.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93548,2020,Severe Mental Illness in Urban Context,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. EHM van Rijen', 'dr. FL Truijens']",,"Inhoud

In this course you will study severe mental illnesses such as psychotic spectrum disorders, and their comorbid conditions. In an urban context, severe mental problems not only go hand in hand with other unfavorable psychological conditions such as violence, substance use and dissociation but also require a different approach when it comes to diagnosis and treatment. People with chronic psychotic symptoms, whether or not in combination with several social problems such as homelessness and forensic problems, often require a more multidisciplinary approach in which not only their symptoms are treated but a case management approach with assertive outreach elements is needed.

In this course you will learn the etiological aspects of severe mental illnesses on psychological level (“which psychological variables are involved”?), biological level (“what goes wrong in the brain”?) and societal level (“what is the role of urban context”?). You will learn to identify severe mental illnesses and learn to take a critical position regarding DSM-driven diagnosis and learn alternative diagnostical systems such as RDOC or holistic person-driven approaches. Information from previous courses will be integrated in this course and you will learn that severe mental illnesses are almost always combined with other disorders and/or severe social problems. You will learn appropriate treatment approaches for these problems (care vs. cure) and learn about the legal and ethical constrains of these treatments.</body>
<body>At the end of this course, the student knows how to
• Describe the diagnostic and etiological aspects of complex mental problems at a psychological, biological, and societal level.
• Identify complex mental disorders related to psychosis.
• Explain the relation between severe mental illness with substance use, violence and other comorbid psychological issues, especially within the urban context.
• Take a critical stance towards the use of the DSM and other diagnostic approaches in clinical practice and scientific research.
• Make an informed choice for an intervention/treatment plan, with consideration of legal and ethical aspects and restrictions.
• Reflect on his/her own role as a psychologist within a multidisciplinary team.
<body>Attendance is mandatory for three tutorial group meetings in weeks 2-4. Students are urged to attend the lectures before the tutorial group meetings.</body>

<body>The following simulation techniques will be covered:
• Basic set-up of a Discrete-event simulation model
• Formulating complex econometric and OR problems in a simulation model.
• Methods to generate realisations of random variables
• Being able to formulate independently a complex econometric / OR problem into a simulation model.

• Being able to implement a simulation model using either Java or Matlab.
prof. dr. B.F. Heidergott (VU), dr. A.A.N Ridder (VU)

This course addresses the use of computer simulation for the analysis and optimization of stochastic dynamic models. Applications will stem from a wide range of domains from Financial Engineering and Business Processes.

This course gives a broad treatment of the important aspects of Monte Carlo simulation and its applications in areas such as inventory control, project planning, reliability, risk analysis and financial models. The emphasis is on modeling the stochastic dynamic system as a discrete event system, and analyzing and improving its performance by means of discrete event simulation. The topics covered include generating random numbers, selecting input distributions and model validation. The course also teaches the statistical output analysis and the use of simulation in optimization and learning.
<body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
• conduct Monte Carlo simulation-based analysis of a problem and provide an output analysis,
• apply simulation in optimization and learning, and to report on their findings.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93083,2020,Small Business Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. CA Rietveld'],,Inhoud

The small business is the most common type of business in every modern economy, and it is not just a scaled-down version of a large business. The course 'Small Business Economics' is about the importance of small businesses and entrepreneurship for markets and economies. Amongst others, we discuss differences between small and large businesses, how small business ownership and entrepreneurship are related, how entrepreneurs exploit and deal with uncertainty, how small businesses contribute to economic growth, and how small businesses can attract finance. Lectures are organized around central questions (see the syllabus). During the course, two group assignments need to be completed on timely topics in the field of small business economics.
• Introduction to the role of small businesses, start-ups and nascent ventures in the economy.
• Introduction to the differences between small and large firms both from an external perspective (economy, market) and from an internal perspective (management, organisation).
• Introduction to the specifics of small business finance.
• Mining publicly available data about small businesses and entrepreneurship for stylised facts using basic statistical tools.
This course will be taught fully online. Therefore, in each course week we will have live Zoom sessions and (prerecorded) lectures.
The course materials and assignment have been updated to reflect the most recent developments in the field of small business economics.
Moreover, the number of case studies discussed in the course has been increased.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/91876,2020,Smart and Shared Cities: The world is changing and becoming ""smart"", but how do we ensure it is “SHARED”?",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['A Psyllidis', 'AJ Klievink', 'dr. A Ersoy', 'dr. AR Ingrams', 'dr. JM Engelbert', 'dr.ir. EA Rijshouwer', 'drs. J de Jong, MSc', 'EM Leclercq', 'L Meilof', 'MJ Slotboom, MSc', 'prof.dr. EA van Zoonen']",,"Inhoud

By 2050, two-thirds of the population will live in cities and new urban citizens will reside in cities that are yet to be developed. These developing smart cities need hands-on though visionary designers to create better living conditions and to reinvent citizenship together with the best technologies. The aim of this minor is to introduce students from the LDE universities to the different smart city concepts and the underlying complexity of modern cities through case-based education. This program intends to stimulate a reflective mindset, focusing on the interrelation of problems and responsible innovation.

The increasing size of modern cities, as well as their day-to-day growing complexity, necessitate that city stakeholders incorporate information and communication technologies in the provision of municipal public services. At the same time, they should include citizens and other stakeholders in the design of these services and technologies, while safeguarding the efficiency. In short: there is an urgency to make the smart city a shared city for all urban stakeholders. We need professionals who understand the fallacy of a ‘technological fix’ and are knowledgeable about urban challenges and data potential, uphold public values and can work in complex environments and teams. These multilevel challenges run through this minor, in which the main learning goals concern the articulation of urban technologies and data science with citizen experience and multi-stakeholder governance.
column2: The learning goals concern knowledge, attitude and skills which in combination need to equip students with a critical mindset that enables them to work towards public needs and interests in smart cities. This minor is multidisciplinary and built on a combination of data, urban, political and social sciences.

column1: This minor is built on a combination of data, urban, political and social sciences. This multidisciplinary minor is open to all students who are interested in the development of smart and shared cities. The minor is offered in English and accessible for both national and international students.

The minor consists of three modules of 5 EC each for the 15 EC variety. The 30 EC variety holds four modules of 5 EC and 10 EC research work in one of the research labs of the Centre for BOLD Cities and the Vital Cities, Vital Citizens program. The format and modules include classic and innovative teaching methods, i.e. lectures and seminars, field trips, case-based group assignments, video production, blogging and logbooks and the integration of academia and practice.

The aim of the minor is to introduce students from the LDE universities through case-based education to the different smart city concepts and the underlying complexity of modern cities, focused on urban technologies and data science with citizen experience and multi-stakeholder governance. The program is characterized by a multi-disciplinary approach, which allows students to take different perspectives and understand the complexity of smart city life. The program intends to stimulate a reflective mindset, focusing on the interrelation of problems and responsible innovation. The learning goals concern knowledge, attitude and skills which in combination need to equip students with a critical mindset that enables them to work towards public needs and interests in smart cities.

Knowledge: Upon completion of the minor, the student will know what a smart city is and how the associated definitions and discourses produce a particular technological and data practice in which particular concerns and interests take privilege over others. S/he will also understand the kind of participatory spaces that are created by and for citizens, and the competing governance models that smart cities advocate. The student will also have a basic insight in the various data and analytics that are relevant to the development of smart cities.

Attitude: Students will develop a critical but constructive attitude towards different views and opinions about the smart city. They will value the contrasting perspectives of private and public stakeholders and will be able to adapt to and explain different views, suggest different solutions and prioritize advices based on different cases with different values. The core ethos of the minor concerns, however, public values in the smart cities, which are encapsulated in the SHARED principles and ethics that underlie various Dutch digital agendas and have been adopted by the VSNU.
Skills: Upon completion of the minor, students will be able to recognize particular interests and values in smart city discourse and practice
column2: they will be able to choose appropriate data for specific urban challenges (critical thinking and information literacy)
column3: they will be able to work in multidisciplinary and trans-sectoral teams and adapt to particular team requirements and collaborative styles (collaboration and communication). For the 30 EC minor, an additional set of skills (e.g. Initiative and technology literacy) will be acquired through internships and projects in the research labs.

column1: Since this is a Leiden-Delft-Erasmus minor, the location of where education is offered difference per module.&nbsp

Deficiencies of students’ knowledge will be tackled at the beginning of each module. Each module will begin with an online quiz that will provide the student with a list of material for self-study to align the knowledge base of students from the various disciplines. All modules will be given in a blended form, i.e. partly face-to-face (e.g. lectures) and partly online (e.g. video’s, web lectures, online documents).

This program is specially developed for students from Leiden University, Delft University of Technology and Erasmus University Rotterdam. The purpose of this minor programme is to educate professionals from different fields such social, economic, environmental engineering and political science on the importance of the different aspects in the use of Big, Open and Linked Data within creating the smart and shared city.

A point of attention regarding the different students and the diversity in study background, as this means that students will most likely have different entry levels. This is considered while designing the programme and the prerequisites to participate. By blending education and using online and offline tools, teachers can check the levels of knowledge of the students upon entry of the course and eventually supply them with relevant background materials to get up to speed.

For this minor there is a balance between traditional and innovative learning methods. The modules are designed in a blended learning form, meaning lectures will make use of face-to-face lectures, online documents and articles, and video’s/online lectures. Reading materials include policy papers, reports, articles and books. We will use Canvas as the electronic teaching environment.

It is possible for EUR students to complete the minor for 15 EC (modules 1, 2 and 3). EUR students can also choose to complete the minor as a whole for 30 EC. The extra 15 EC is extra curricular. To include the extra 15 EC in your Bachelor program, EUR students need to ask permission from their Exam Board.
• Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University

• Content: In this first module the students will be introduced to the core ideas of the smart city and technologies. The module will cover the historical development of the smart city concept and address the various functions of smart city discourse. It will also explain the basic digital and data technologies (key enabling technologies) that constitute smart cities, and discuss the various methodologies to involve citizens and users (key enabling methodologies). There will also be ample attention for the legal, ethical, political and social dilemmas in smart cities. The module will simultaneously introduce students to the most common theories of urban studies, urbanism and urbanization.
• Teaching method(s): reading, guest lecture, field trip and video.
• Faculty: Faculty Governance and Global Affairs, Leiden University

• Content: Data and digital technologies offer both great potential for cities and great risks. In this module we discuss the effects of platform capital in cities, in the form of, among others, AirBnB and Uber. We explore the various responses from banning (as in Barcelona) to regulating (as in Amsterdam) and free entry (as in many other cities in the world). We will show the political-economic interests of these platforms and discuss the European regulations and attempts at curtailing them. We also zoom in on the way cities themselves explore the use of digital and data technologies and which models of regulation and participation they have developed. The module will have a strong public input from public administration perspectives and discuss how different governance ideologies (new public management vs new public service) produce different understandings of what a smart city should achieve.
• Teaching method(s): reading, online lecture, guest lecture, online library/ toolkit and groupwork
Module 3: Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city
• Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University

• Content: Many of the smart city projects are framed as producing solutions to large challenges in cities, regarding, among others, the environment, mobility, security and safety. In addition, there is a strong articulation of ‘smart city’ with open data, citizen participation and start-up economy. In this module we approach the smart city from the perspective of the citizen and the social fabric in the city. Who benefits from smart city developments, whose interests are served? Which groups miss out, and how is everyday life in streets, stores, pubs and clubs affected? In this module we discuss the contrast between technologies of care and service, versus control and surveillance. We pay special attention to the ever expanding array of smart forms of co-creation as opposed to forms of ‘sousveillance’ and ‘coveillance’. Both the civic non-response to the smart city, and the political, artistic and design interventions will be theoretically and empirically addressed.
• Teaching method(s): online reading, documentary, response lecture, research presentation and living lab.

column4: Introduction to the smart city - Origins and functions of the smart city
Introduction to the smart city - Identify and explain enabling technologies and methodologies
Introduction to the smart city - Position yourself in the debate
Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city - Exploring the digital and social division
Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city - Citizens' responsibility
Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city - Applying the tools to mobilize citizens
Governing the smart city - The ‘force field’:&nbsp
Governing the smart city - Consequences for governance: Tolerance for complexity

column3: Governing the smart city - Designing instruments

column14: &nbsp

column1: At the end of block A the student hands in a portfolio and an individual assessment takes place. In the portfolio assignments are collected that had to be completed during the minor. This shows that the student has achieved the learning objectives. The student will explain their own learning process in the assessment. The assessors will ask questions to arrive at the conclusion whether the student meets the learning objectives of the minor.

column2: Other forms of testing may include:

column1: • Individual essay (1500 words with critical reflection on another group project)

Essays with corrections and feedback will be returned to the students. There will be a feedback moment after each of the assignments. The lecturer provides written or oral feedback on the individual assignment and the group assignment.
No final marks are given between 5.0 and 6.0 and the following rounding rules are used: a 5.5 or higher is rounded to 6.0 and a 5.49 or lower is rounded to 5.0
Outside the 5.0 - 6.0 range, final marks are expressed as a number with one decimal.
Students need to pass each module with a grade of at least 5.5 (there is no compensation) in order to complete the minor.
Each module will have its own grade composition which will be described in the syllabus for the minor.

For students completing this minor, there are generic competences and specific competences to be acquired. The minor programme mainly focuses on skills such as analysing and evaluating (policies/strategies). After completing block A (15 EC programme), students will have acquired specific knowledge on smart cities and how data usage could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants.
After this module students are able to:

column14: Explain the origins and functions of the smart city concept
Identify enabling technologies and methodologies of the smart city
Identify (recognize) and compare the different conceptions of the smart city concept
Position him/herself in the smart city debate, argue for that position and reflect on that Position.

column1: After this module students are able to:

column14: Understand the playing field of smart cities with the use of conceptual models
Understand the consequences of the complexity of smart city playing fields for the governing of the smart city
Design instruments/strategies for interactive governance of the smart city.

column14: Understand the digital &amp
Explain how citizens can take role in city dynamics
Evaluate tools that mobilize groups of citizens.</body>

column1: Since this is a Leiden-Delft-Erasmus minor, the location of where education is offered difference per module.&nbsp

Deficiencies of students’ knowledge will be tackled at the beginning of each module. Each module will begin with an online quiz that will provide the student with a list of material for self-study to align the knowledge base of students from the various disciplines. All modules will be given in a blended form, i.e. partly face-to-face (e.g. lectures) and partly online (e.g. video’s, web lectures, online documents).

This program is specially developed for students from Leiden University, Delft University of Technology and Erasmus University Rotterdam. The purpose of this minor programme is to educate professionals from different fields such social, economic, environmental engineering and political science on the importance of the different aspects in the use of Big, Open and Linked Data within creating the smart and shared city.

A point of attention regarding the different students and the diversity in study background, as this means that students will most likely have different entry levels. This is considered while designing the programme and the prerequisites to participate. By blending education and using online and offline tools, teachers can check the levels of knowledge of the students upon entry of the course and eventually supply them with relevant background materials to get up to speed.

For this minor there is a balance between traditional and innovative learning methods. The modules are designed in a blended learning form, meaning lectures will make use of face-to-face lectures, online documents and articles, and video’s/online lectures. Reading materials include policy papers, reports, articles and books. We will use Canvas as the electronic teaching environment.

It is possible for EUR students to complete the minor for 15 EC (modules 1, 2 and 3). EUR students can also choose to complete the minor as a whole for 30 EC. The extra 15 EC is extra curricular. To include the extra 15 EC in your Bachelor program, EUR students need to ask permission from their Exam Board.
• Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University

• Content: In this first module the students will be introduced to the core ideas of the smart city and technologies. The module will cover the historical development of the smart city concept and address the various functions of smart city discourse. It will also explain the basic digital and data technologies (key enabling technologies) that constitute smart cities, and discuss the various methodologies to involve citizens and users (key enabling methodologies). There will also be ample attention for the legal, ethical, political and social dilemmas in smart cities. The module will simultaneously introduce students to the most common theories of urban studies, urbanism and urbanization.
• Teaching method(s): reading, guest lecture, field trip and video.
• Faculty: Faculty Governance and Global Affairs, Leiden University

• Content: Data and digital technologies offer both great potential for cities and great risks. In this module we discuss the effects of platform capital in cities, in the form of, among others, AirBnB and Uber. We explore the various responses from banning (as in Barcelona) to regulating (as in Amsterdam) and free entry (as in many other cities in the world). We will show the political-economic interests of these platforms and discuss the European regulations and attempts at curtailing them. We also zoom in on the way cities themselves explore the use of digital and data technologies and which models of regulation and participation they have developed. The module will have a strong public input from public administration perspectives and discuss how different governance ideologies (new public management vs new public service) produce different understandings of what a smart city should achieve.
• Teaching method(s): reading, online lecture, guest lecture, online library/ toolkit and groupwork
Module 3: Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city
• Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University

• Content: Many of the smart city projects are framed as producing solutions to large challenges in cities, regarding, among others, the environment, mobility, security and safety. In addition, there is a strong articulation of ‘smart city’ with open data, citizen participation and start-up economy. In this module we approach the smart city from the perspective of the citizen and the social fabric in the city. Who benefits from smart city developments, whose interests are served? Which groups miss out, and how is everyday life in streets, stores, pubs and clubs affected? In this module we discuss the contrast between technologies of care and service, versus control and surveillance. We pay special attention to the ever expanding array of smart forms of co-creation as opposed to forms of ‘sousveillance’ and ‘coveillance’. Both the civic non-response to the smart city, and the political, artistic and design interventions will be theoretically and empirically addressed.
• Teaching method(s): online reading, documentary, response lecture, research presentation and living lab.
• Faculty: TU Delft Faculty of Industrial Design Engineering, Delft University of Technology

• Content: This course aims to inform students about the big range of geosocial big data technologies such as sensing devices, GPS trackers, social media and massive government and public data repositories within modern cities. Lectures from data science and urban planning discuss the present and future of (spatial) data science applications in urban and regional contexts.
• Teaching method(s): readings, online tutorial, groupwork and field trip

• Faculty: Faculty of Architecture and the Built Environment, Delft University of Technology, Faculty Governance and Global Affairs, Leiden University, Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University

<li>Content: This course will put all the theory the students had in the previous modules into practice. The students will be able to participate in research practices of existing research projects. Prior to the project, the Centre for BOLD Cities will organize a ""market"" with research topics and projects, which will be brought in from the existing research lines within BOLD Cities and from other smart city projects from the LDE Universities. column1: At the end of block A (modules 1-3) the student hands in a portfolio and an individual assessment takes place. In the portfolio assignments are collected that had to be completed during the minor. This shows that the student has achieved the learning objectives. The student will explain their own learning process in the assessment. The assessors will ask questions to arrive at the conclusion whether the student meets the learning objectives of the minor.

column2: Other forms of testing may include:

column1: • Individual essay (1500 words with critical reflection on another group project)

Essays with corrections and feedback will be returned to the students. There will be a feedback moment after each of the assignments. The lecturer provides written or oral feedback on the individual assignment and the group assignment.
No final marks are given between 5.0 and 6.0 and the following rounding rules are used: a 5.5 or higher is rounded to 6.0 and a 5.49 or lower is rounded to 5.0
Outside the 5.0 - 6.0 range, final marks are expressed as a number with one decimal.
Students need to pass each module with a grade of at least 5.5 (there is no compensation) in order to complete the minor.
Each module will have its own grade composition which will be described in the syllabus for the minor.

For students completing this minor, there are generic competences and specific competences to be acquired. The minor programme mainly focuses on skills such as analysing and evaluating (policies/strategies). After completing block A (15 EC programme), students will have acquired specific knowledge on smart cities and how data usage could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants. After completing block B (30 EC programme), students will have acquired knowledge about urban data science, its advantages and limitations and how it could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants. The knowledge that students will acquire in these modules will be applied in a case project, where theory is applied in practice by means of a research project.
After this module students are able to:

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95050,2020,Sociaal Medische wetenschappen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. M Vollmann', 'dr. MD Hilverda', 'dr. RA Scheepers', 'PI Crompvoets, MSc', 'prof.dr. AP Nieboer', 'prof.dr. PHM van Baal']",,"Inhoud

Wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte en gezondheid vormt de basis van de medische praktijk in onze westerse samenlevingen. Deze kennis over ziekte is, met het huidige biomedische model als uitgangspunt, van betrekkelijk recente datum: het eind van de 19e eeuw. In dit vak bestuderen studenten deze biomedische kennis, onder meer aan de hand van een aantal in Nederland veel voorkomende gezondheidsproblemen. Aan de hand hiervan zal tegelijkertijd duidelijk worden dat de huidige wetenschappelijke kennis het resultaat is van sociale en culturele factoren. Kennis is dan ook veelal historisch bepaald. Door middel van deze meer (medisch) sociologische visie krijgen studenten inzicht in de ""constructivistische"" zienswijze op wetenschappelijke kennis over gezondheid en ziekte.

Gezondheidsproblemen komen niet in dezelfde mate voor in verschillende bevolkingsgroepen. Zo zijn er verschillen naar geslacht en leeftijd, maar ook naar sociaaleconomische positie en etnische herkomst. Om dit te bestuderen is demografische en epidemiologische basiskennis nodig om gezondheidsproblemen en deze relevante factoren te meten en om de onderlinge relaties vast te stellen.

Bovendien worden basale modellen ter verklaring van dergelijke verschillen in gezondheid geïntroduceerd, evenals modellen ter verklaring van verschillen in het omgaan met ziekte (gezondheidspsychologie) en in het zoeken van hulp. Een belangrijke factor hierbij zijn de zogenaamde ""lekenopvattingen"" van ziekte en gezondheid. Immers, de wetenschappelijke kennis over ziekte wordt ook vandaag niet door alle bevolkingsgroepen in dezelfde mate gedeeld. Inzicht in deze ""lekenopvattingen"" is belangrijk vanwege de invloed op de omgang met ziekte en het zorggebruik, waaronder bijvoorbeeld de therapietrouw.

Uit voorgaande beschrijving wordt duidelijk dat de sociaal medische wetenschappen bestaan uit verschillende disciplines. Studenten maken daarom kennis met de biomedische geneeskunde, (medische) sociologie, demografie, epidemiologie en gezondheidspsychologie.

De beoogde doelstellingen worden bijgebracht aan de hand van hoorcolleges en werkgroepen. In de hoorcolleges worden de basisconcepten, -modellen en relevante theorieën toegelicht. In de werkgroepen worden deze inzichten toegepast aan de hand van een aantal geselecteerde gezondheidsproblemen. Daarbij wordt gekozen voor voorbeelden van uiteenlopende aard: infectieziekten, chronische gezondheidsproblemen en psychische problematiek.
De student kan na het volgen van deze cursus…
• de disciplines binnen Sociaal Medische Wetenschappen (SMW) –biomedische geneeskunde, epidemiologie, demografie, (medische) sociologie en gezondheidspsychologie – in eigen woorden omschrijven
• objectieve en subjectieve gezondheidsmaten van gezondheidsverschillen in eigen woorden omschrijven
• uitleggen wat primaire, secundaire en tertiaire preventie is
• modellen van arts-patiënt relaties (consensusmodel, conflictmodel, onderhandelingsmodel en contractmodel) toepassen op een casus
• de ervaring van ziekte verklaren aan de hand van gezondheidspsychologische theorieën (het stress-copingmodel en het common-sense model)
• gezondheidsgedrag verklaren op basis van het HAPA-model en het Health Belief model
• uitleggen hoe de betekenis van ziekte en gezondheid onderhevig is aan tijd en cultuur
• de verschillende sociologische theorieën van ziekte en gezondheid (functionalisme, symbolisch interactionisme, marxisme, sociaal constructivisme en de labelling theorie) uitleggen

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92820,2020,Sociaal wetenschappelijk onderzoek in de praktijk,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JA Holland', 'dr. JFA Braster', 'F de Haan']",,"Inhoud

Deze cursus introduceert diverse sociale wetenschapsonderzoeken perspectieven en methodologieën. Door deze cursus wordt jouw begrip van filosofische, theoretische en ethische kwesties die van belang zijn voor het doen van onderzoek verbreed, en krijg je meer inzicht in de relatie tussen theorie en onderzoek in de praktijk.

Om meer inzicht in het onderzoeksproces te krijgen—van idee tot onderzoeksdesign tot de productie van nieuwe kennis— volgt de cursus twee afzonderlijke, doch aan elkaar verbonden, paden. Het eerste pad betreft het aanleren van methoden van data verzamelen, data analyse en de interpretatie van de analyses. Het tweede pad bestaat uit het tonen van voorbeelden van onderzoek te tonen die gebruik maken van: kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve methoden, innovatieve dataverzamelings- en analysetechnieken, ‘natural experiements’, en creatieve vergelijkingen van verschillende hypotheses.

Deze cursus bestrijkt algemene onderwerpen zoals: wetenschappelijke integriteit, epistemologie, ethiek, ‘mixed’ methoden en ‘big data.’ Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan een reeks (zogenaamde) kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve onderzoeksmethoden.

Daarnaast geeft deze cursus je een methodologische basis voor de verdere ontwikkeling van je methodologische gereedschapskist en draagt de cursus bij aan de ontwikkeling en het management van je eigen onderzoeksprojecten (in het bijzonder je masterscriptie). De geleerde onderzoeksvaardigheden zijn niet alleen binnen, maar ook buiten de wetenschap (zowel in de publieke als private sector) van belang voor een socioloog.
Na de voltooiing van deze cursus kun je:
• De basale wetenschapsfilosofische componenten van diverse methodologieën in de sociale wetenschappen uitleggen (bijv. naturalisme, constructivisme).
<li>De principes van ethiek, privacy en wetenschappelijke integriteit in sociaal onderzoek uitleggen en toepassen
<li>Beantwoordbare sociaalwetenschappelijke onderzoeksvragen formuleren, alsmede aangeven welke data en analyses het beste bij die vragen aansluiten
<li>Verslagen van empirisch sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek evalueren en bepalen in hoeverre zij antwoorden bieden op de gestelde onderzoeksvragen
<li>De belangrijkste benaderingen in kwalitatieve dataverzameling begrijpen (interviewen, observatie, documenten en combinaties daarvan (bijv. etnografisch onderzoek))
<li>De belangrijkste procedures voor de analyse van kwalitatieve data en interpretatie van resultaten begrijpen en beschrijven (coderen, contentanalyse, discours analyse en grounded theory)
<li>De belangrijkste benaderingen in kwantitatieve dataverzameling begrijpen (enquêtes, experimenten en het gebruik van secundaire kwantitatieve data)
<li>Verschillende technieken voor de analyse van kwantitatieve data en interpretatie van resultaten begrijpen en beschrijven (verschillende typen regressieanalyses)
<li>De rol van mixed methods en triangulatie in sociologisch onderzoek begrijpen en beschrijven
• De belangrijkste benaderingen in evaluatieonderzoek begrijpen en beschrijven (random control trials, quasi-experimentele designs, realistic evaluation).
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95201,2020,Social Choice Theory and Political Representation,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. S Wintein'],,Inhoud
<body>This course is part of cluster 1: Representation: Democracy, Science, and Culture.&nbsp

When multiple criteria (such as the preferences of different voters) give rise to different orderings of some set of alternatives (such as candidates running for election), the following question arises: how should one aggregate the different orderings into a single ``taking-all-criteria-into-account” ordering of the alternatives? That question is the central question of Social Choice Theory. Answers to the question crucially depend on the type of information that may be used in the aggregation. In the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory, only ordinal information is allowed. In the traditional framework, answers to the central question are constrained by impossibility results such as Arrow’s theorem, which, very roughly, state that no adequate aggregation method exists. In the literature, various ways to escape these impossibility results have been proposed that all involve, in one way or the other, leaving Social Choice Theory’s traditional framework.

An attempt to aggregate individual preferences into “the societal preference” is often described as an attempt to capture “the will of the people”. This illustrates that the (impossibility) results of Social Choice Theory are important for our thinking about representative democracy and, more generally, political representation. This course is an introduction to Social Choice Theory and a discussion of the relevance of its results for voting systems and political representation.
<body>1. The student can name the basic assumptions of the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory, is able to give definitions of its central notions (e.g.&nbsp
column5: social welfare function) and can explain the relevance of Social Choice Theory for voting theory / welfare economics.

column1: 2. The student is familiar with various often-used Social Welfare Functions (e.g.&nbsp
column4: Borda rule) and is able to apply these functions (to compute e.g. the outcome of elections).

column2: The student is familiar with various properties (e.g. monotonicity, IIA, Pareto, strategic manipulability) for SWFs, is able to discuss the desirability of these properties in a voting / policy context and is able to explain how often-used SWFs fare with respect to these properties.

column1: 4. The student is able to explain which properties for SWFs are mutually incompatible, is familiar with Arrow’s Impossibility Theorem and Sen’s Impossibility Theorem and is able to comment on the significance of these impossibility theorems in a in a voting / policy context.
5. The student is able to explain how, by giving up certain features of the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory (e.g.&nbsp
column3: or transitivity of social orderings), the impossibility theorems can be escaped.

column1: 6. The student is familiar with the Balinski-Laraki framework for Social Choice Theory, able to give definitions of its central notions (e.g.&nbsp
column4: majority judgement) and able to critically compare the traditional framework of Social Choice Theory with the Balinski-Laraki framework.

Social entrepreneurship is an emerging field of academic study and real-world practice. At its core, social entrepreneurship pertains the combination of market-based and nonprofit approaches to solve social issues, a feat social entrepreneurs achieve by combining the knowledge and skills used in traditional business with a passionate commitment to having a meaningful and sustainable social impact. By combining insights from the academic literature with real cases and scenarios, the course will introduce students to both theory and practice of social entrepreneurship.
Each week, the course will focus on one important aspect or theme of social entrepreneurship, through two types of lectures: a “theoretical” lecture and a “seminar” lecture.

column4: “Theoretical” lectures will compose the first appointment of each one of the six weeks of the course. These lectures will take the form of traditional frontal lectures where the lecturer will cover the material related to the week’s topic.

“Seminar” lectures will instead compose the second appointment of each week and will focus on interweaving the theoretical content covered in previous lectures with real case scenarios and practical exercises. Such lectures will be interactive in nature, with in-class exercises (both individual and in groups), case-studies, and contributions from guest practitioners.

column1: The six weeks of the course will cover the following topics

column4: Week 1. Social Entrepreneurship: definition and characteristics
Week 2. Social entrepreneurs and opportunities recognition
Week 3. Social enterprises as hybrid organizations
Week 4. Business models in social enterprises
Week 5. Scaling impact in social entrepreneurship

column1: The goal of the course is to expose students to the field of Social Entrepreneurship. At the end of the course students will be able to:

column4: Recognize the different types of social entrepreneurial action and its characteristics.&nbsp
Examine the opportunities opened by social entrepreneurship in comparison to normal entrepreneurship.
Evaluate the typical challenges faced by social enterprises.
Design social entrepreneurial models coherently combining commercial and social value creation.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94358,2020,Social Inequalities: An introduction,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. BE French'],,Inhoud

What are dimensions of inequality? How unequal are societies in which we live? Is it getting better or worse? What factors determine these trends? In this course, students will develop the tools necessary to critically evaluate such questions. Students gain an overview in the many dimensions of inequality in contemporary societies (e.g. economic, ethnic, gender, spatial). We will look both within societies and across societies to develop an understanding of how inequality manifests in local and international contexts. Special attention is given to the mechanism through which these inequalities are produced and reproduced in social institutions like school, neighborhood and workplace. Furthermore, we will focus on the consequences of social inequalities in terms of individuals’ wellbeing and health. Students will learn how researchers study these processes in national and international contexts. They will learn about the challenges facing scholarship, and participate in key debates that animate contemporary inequalities research.
After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Explore central concepts through which sociologists investigate inequality.

2. Develop a descriptive and analytical understanding of how class, gender, ethnicity and other dimensions of inequality impact interactions, institutional placements, choices, and social policy in contemporary societies.
3. Become familiar with key debates that animate contemporary research on inequality.
4. Consider and critique competing explanations for social stratification and social mobility.
5. Learn about how these concepts are applied in quantitative, qualitative and mixed-methods empirical research.
After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skill:
1. Be able to write an academic paper on patterns, causes and consequences of social inequalities.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/96591,2020,Social Media Campaigns,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval'],,"Inhoud

Social media campaigns is a research seminar with a deceptively simple goal: understand to understand how organizations (may) use social media for strategic benefit and explore the academic research being done around the subject. Guiding research questions include: To what end/for what purposes are organizations using social media, how organizations may realize the benefit/ROI from using social media, what are the parameters for ‘success’ in such campaigns, the (theoretical and pragmatic) differences among various social media, what motivates audiences to participate and interact with brands, and how organizations might invite such identifications.

The primary methods of learning in this course discussions, shorts lectures on cases, and individual or group empirical research. By examining and evaluating campaigns/cases, participants will construct and generate collective understanding of social media campaigns—their goals, strategies, and specific tactics—and apply these understandings for their own empirical thesis project. This seminar is specifically recommended for students that are already writing their thesis around the use of social media campaigns by either organizations or individuals.

Social Media Campaigns is a research seminar oriented to explore research done around the strategic benefit that organizations and individuals get from their online campaigning. During the seminar, we will discuss the state of the art of social media campaign research and discussions, as well as to work collectively with the colleagues in their own research projects (thesis).
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95126,2020,Social Media Data Analytics for Business,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud
dr. C.S. Bos (VU) and dr. I.D. Lindner (VU)
This course provides an overview on how to collect, analyze and interpret social media data for business strategies and research.

Social media data analysis is indispensable for businesses of all sizes. Social media provide a platform for customers to share reviews of products, they indicate directions in which the market develops and represent a powerful tool for marketing purposes. This course delves, handson, into the wealth of social media data which is readily available, and the manners in which this data can be collected, analyzed, and put to good use for business strategies and research. For this purpose, the course applies the advances in tools available, covering the use of sentiment analysis, basic machine learning and artificial intelligence for extracting the information in social media posts.
After this course, students will be able to
1. Collect data from social media services such as Twitter and YouTube using Application Programming Interfaces (API’s) and basic web scrapers.
2. Clean, visualize and analyze data from various social media services.
3. Analyze textual comments for sentiments expressed in them.
4. Understand the theory of social media communication networks.
5. Identify trends for business strategies and set up models for research and development purposes.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92220,2020,Social Media Marketing,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. M Scalvini'],,"Inhoud
<body>This course offers a combination of theory and practice designed to prepare students for entry level jobs in social media marketing.&nbsp
column2: We discuss relevant theoretical knowledge about marketing communication, but we also strive to teach you the practical skills which are essential for a career in social media marketing.

column1: In this course, you are invited to challenge the mainstream concepts of marketing communication from a cultural and social perspective. We analyse the strategies that companies employ online in various industries (e.g., fashion, technology, cosmetics) and research new trends such as sustainability, diversity, and brand activism. We also look at narrative aspects of social media advertising such as originality, creativity and storytelling.

The main goal of the course is to meld essential theory with practical application and cover core skills such as strategic planning for social media applications, branding, business communications, and harnessing social media data to yield consumer insights. We achieve this goal through case studies, creative brainstorming, research activities, teamwork and the contribution of social media marketing experts from Adidas, American Express, Aperol/Campari, Unilever, and VanMoof.

This course was previously called ""Social Media Strategies in Business Communication"" but it is still the same course. If you already took CM2274 or CM2074 under the old name, please note that you cannot take this course.
<li>·the cultural and social implications for both marketers and consumers
<li>·the elements of social identity, how individuals build their social identities, and why identities are relevant to marketers
<li>·how some of the world’s leading brands have successfully applied content and digital media into their strategies
<li>·focus on emerging trends in digital culture, consumer behavior, and data analytics
<li>·analyze and apply marketing strategies for social media

<body>This course offers a combination of theory and practice designed to prepare students for entry level jobs in social media marketing.&nbsp
column2: We discuss relevant theoretical knowledge about marketing communication, but we also strive to teach you the practical skills which are essential for a career in social media marketing.

column1: In this course, you are invited to challenge the mainstream concepts of marketing communication from a cultural and social perspective. We analyse the strategies that companies employ online in various industries (e.g., fashion, technology, cosmetics) and research new trends such as sustainability, diversity, and brand activism. We also look at narrative aspects of social media advertising such as originality, creativity and storytelling.

The main goal of the course is to meld essential theory with practical application and cover core skills such as strategic planning for social media applications, branding, business communications, and harnessing social media data to yield consumer insights. We achieve this goal through case studies, creative brainstorming, research activities, teamwork and the contribution of social media marketing experts from Adidas, American Express, Aperol/Campari, Unilever, and VanMoof.

This course was previously called ""Social Media Strategies in Business Communication"" but it is still the same course. If you already took CM2074 or CM2274 under the old name, please note that you cannot take this course.
<li>the cultural and social implications for both marketers and consumers
<li>the elements of social identity, how individuals build their social identities, and why identities are relevant to marketers
<li>how some of the world’s leading brands have successfully applied content and digital media into their strategies
<li>focus on emerging trends in digital culture, consumer behavior, and data analytics
<li>analyze and apply marketing strategies for social media
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92274,2020,Social Media Use,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. M Slot'],,"Inhoud
<body>Digitization, convergence and connectivity have enabled organizations in the cultural industries to boost the social aspect of their audience relations
column2: users are not only just recipients of media content, but can participate and create value themselves. This participative culture impacts the way organizations in the creative industries function. But how exactly? The possibilities are endless – audiences can be brand ambassadors and aid in the viral marketing of their cultural products. They can be invited for co-creation projects through social media. They are enabled to take up distribution roles in peer-to-peer networks, create content, comment, review, publish, share, download, upload, remix and communicate by means of social networks such as Instagram, Snapchat, YouTube, Twitter or Facebook. Social media also pose challenges for organizations in the creative industries: What if your audience is not engaged? What are the motivations for people to become actively involved? What if your creative product causes a strong reaction on social media? Or how should you tell your story online?

column1: In this research workshop, the use of social media in the creative industries will be our research domain. You are free to choose your own perspective – the producer side or the user side. By means of qualitative research methods, you will explore and analyze a self-chosen topic in more depth. You will design and execute your own empirical research, and report about your findings in our peer-reviewed academic journal: the Erasmus Journal of Social Media.
• State-of-the-art theory on the topic of this workshop.
• Current research designs and methods to examine social media use.
• Design and execute a small-scale empirical research
• Report about the results of their research both in written and oral form.
• Critically reflect on the constraints and societal implications of their research.
• Constructively work as part of a team.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92687,2020,Social Psychology: People in Groups,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AMF Hiemstra', 'SA Roest, MSc']",,"Inhoud

De opleiding Psychologie van de Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam wordt gekenmerkt door probleemgestuurd onderwijs (PGO). Voor studenten zal dit een eerste kennismaking zijn met een onderwijsvorm waarin gewerkt wordt aan de hand van problemen binnen een kleine groep studenten (de onderwijsgroep). Om binnen dit onderwijssysteem goed te functioneren is een aantal vaardigheden, zoals het leiden van een gesprek, notuleren, informatie zoeken etc. van groot belang. Hieraan zal tijdens de training dan ook uitgebreid aandacht worden besteed. Het tweede belangrijk onderdeel van dit blok is een kennismaking met de sociale psychologie. De sociale psychologie is een deelgebied van de psychologie dat zich richt op hoe mensen elkaars gedrag, denken en voelen beïnvloeden. Je zult kennismaken met enkele klassieke thema's uit de sociale psychologie, zoals attributie van gedrag en attitudes. Een ander thema dat in meerdere problemen terugkomt, is de invloed van de groep op het individu. Groepen kunnen bijvoorbeeld een groot effect hebben op hoe goed wij presteren en hoe bereid wij zijn anderen te helpen. Ook passen wij ons gedrag sterk aan aan dat van de groep en kunnen we zelfs in een groep onze eigen identiteit verliezen. De sociale psychologie is een subdiscipline die vaak als leuk en interessant wordt ervaren. Dit is niet in de laatste plaats omdat deze zo dicht staat bij de ervaringen van elke dag en je bij uitstek laat nadenken over je eigen gedrag en dat van mensen om je heen.
Dit blok heeft de volgende zaken tot doel:

• Basiskennis verwerven op het gebied van de sociale psychologie. Meer specifiek wordt kennis verworven rondom de volgende thema’s: hulpgedrag, attitudes en attitudeverandering, conformisme, sociale facilitatie en social loafing, deïndividuatie, gehoorzaamheid, sociale perceptie en attributie van gedrag, stereotypen en vooroordelen, en affiliatie en attractie.

• Kennismaking met probleemgestuurd onderwijs (PGO) en training in vaardigheden die voor PGO belangrijk zijn, maar ook in algemene studievaardigheden. Dit zijn onder meer het werken met de Zevensprong, het gesprek leiden, notuleren, luisteren en samenvatten, feedback geven voor PGO. Meer algemeen wordt er aandacht besteed aan het leren zoeken van informatie, het bestuderen en integreren van de gevonden informatie, leerstijlen en taalvaardigheid.

<body>De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding. For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92044,2020,Social Science Research,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['CA Malig Jedlicki, MSc', 'dr. N Oosterman']",,"Inhoud

<body>This course focuses on the application of qualitative and quantitative research methods in the social sciences with a specific focus of arts, culture, and media. It focuses specifically on interview and survey design, but discusses a wide range of data collection methods both in quantitative and qualitative research. The course furthermore familiarizes students with the full process involved in setting up a research project. During the course, students conduct a qualitative and quantitative research proposal, including research questions, the operationalization of&nbsp
column2: concepts and variables and methods of data collection. Other course activities involve practical&nbsp
column3: assignments that lead to the development of research evaluation skills, research skills, developing&nbsp
column4: research designs, and the critical evaluation of research reports.

column1: This course aims to familiarize students with the main research designs, methods, and techniques of social science research. It provides students with the necessary theoretical and practical knowledge of qualitative and quantitative research methodologies. It furthermore thoroughly discusses the theoretical and philosophical foundations of research paradigms underlining common methodological approaches. After completing this course, the students will be able to:
• Draw theoretical and practical conclusions based on their review of the research literature
• Present their research reviews and plans in a systematic and clear manner, both orally and in writing.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92821,2020,Social Science Research in Practice,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JA Holland', 'dr. JFA Braster']",,"Inhoud

This course introduces a wide range of perspectives on and methodological approaches to social science research. You will broaden your understanding of the philosophical, theoretical and ethical issues that matter in research, and will gain insight in the relationship between theory and research practice.

To gain insight into the research process—from an idea to research design to the production of new knowledge—the course pursues two avenues. One is to help you develop practical skills in data collection, data analysis and interpretation. The other is to present you with exemplars of research using qualitative and quantitative methods, innovative uses of data, natural experiments, and creative comparisons of competing hypotheses.

The course content covers general topics such as scientific integrity, epistemology, ethics, mixed methods and big data. In addition, attention is devoted to a range of so-called quantitative and qualitative research methods.

The course aims to provide you with the methodological foundation to further develop a specialized methodological toolkit and to develop and manage your own (thesis) research projects, and to acquire a set of skills that are sought by government and non-government agencies, and industry.
After successful completion of this course, you will be able to:
<li>Explain the basic philosophical components to various methodologies in the social sciences (e.g. naturalism, constructivism)
<li>Explain and apply the principles of ethics, privacy, and scientific integrity in social research
<li>Formulate answerable social scientific research questions, and identify which data and analyses best match those questions
<li>Evaluate reports of empirical social science research, and assess to what extent they provide answers to the formulated research questions
<li>Understand the main approaches in qualitative data collection, i.e. interview, observation, documents, and combinations thereof (e.g. ethnography)
<li>Understand and describe the main qualitative data analyzing techniques and its procedures to interpret the results, i.e. coding, content analysis, discourse analysis and grounded theory
<li>Understand the main approaches for quantitative data collection, i.e. survey design, experimental design and the use of secondary quantitative data
• Understand and describe techniques for analyzing quantitative data and interpret the results, i.e. various types of regression analysis.
<li>Understand and describe the role of mixed methods and triangulation in sociological research
• Understand and describe the most important approaches in evaluation research (random control trials, quasi-experimental designs, realistic evaluation).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92127,2020,Social and Cultural History,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['CSM Hull, PhD', 'dr. B van Besouw', 'J Quak']",,"Inhoud

Social and cultural history are two disciplines in field of history. They arose in the late nineteenth century in reaction to traditional schools of political, military, and diplomatic history. Initially, social history focused on the experiences of ordinary people and aimed to unearth the structural sources of historical change. Cultural history analyzed cultural expression (for instance art and architecture) and collective mentalities.

Since the “cultural turn” of the 1980s, cultural history has been influenced by post-modernism and post-colonialism. The fields of social and cultural history have also affected one another: for instance, social historians may engage in discourse analysis as part of their investigation into people's lived experiences
column2: and cultural historians may examine the ways in which ordinary people challenged social constructs.

column1: This course offers a broad introduction into the historiography, methods, and theories of both disciplines. After an introduction to social and cultural history, we focus on a number of themes, including travel, women, death, carnival, gender, and revolution.

Students are introduced to the disciplines of social and cultural history. They are acquainted with the history of both disciplines, they can critically assess works of social and cultural historiography and they can apply main theories and methods of both disciplines in academic papers.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95158,2020,Social and Economic Network Analysis,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud
prof. dr. B.F. Heidergott (VU), dr. I.D. Lindner (VU).
This course provides an overview and synthesis of models and techniques for analyzing social and economic networks.

This course discusses the complex “connectedness” of social and economic relationships which is found in numerous incarnations: the rapid growth of the world-wide-web, the ease with which communication takes place, the fast spread of news and information as well as it’s impact on opinion formation and our society. 52 We start with an analytical toolbox of recognizing and analyzing patterns of network data. These tools show how to simplify complexity such as (1) global patterns (degree distributions, path lengths and the small world phenomenon, decomposition of networks), (2) segregation patterns (node types and homophily), (3) local patterns (clustering, transitivity, support) as well as (4) positions in networks (neighborhoods, centrality, influence measures). Next, we will discuss research on network formation and analyze how different model assumptions leave their characteristic footprint on network data. On the one hand, there is the large class of (growing) random networks models which explains a plethora of phenomena (rich-get-richer, small world, social media communication graphs). This class also serves as an important benchmark for identifying non-random properties of networks in which links are formed strategically (business relationships, co-author models). Hybrid models lie in between these two complementary approaches and are able to explain a large class of data (islands-connections model). Finally, we will discuss dynamic implications of the network structure in the context of (1) diffusion through networks (spread of information and diseases, financial contagion) as well as (2) learning and consensus formation on networks (imitation and social influence, wisdom of crowds). Key issues for both classes of dynamics are identifying key actors and their impact on aggregate behavior and beliefs. In particular, these methods allow to analyze the value of individuals in a collectivity (value of players in football teams).

<body>Students will learn fundamental concepts from social network theory that allow to (1) classify network data in terms of structural properties, (2) identify the underlying incentives of network formation aggregate dynamics, and (3) derive context dependent measures and possible policy implications.</body>

<body>We will study the basic concepts and theories of social and political philosophy, and more specifically of political theory, based on the conviction that social and political thought always also has to be understood from the social and political context from which it arose.
