https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95182,2020,Supervised Machine Learning,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['dr. PC Schoonees', 'prof.dr. PJF Groenen']",,"Inhoud
Instructors: prof. dr. P.J.F. Groenen (EUR), dr. P. Schoonees (EUR).

Statistical learning methods arising from statistics, machine learning, and data science have become more widespread available. Machine learning methods can be split in supervised learning with the aim of predicting a response variable and unsupervised learning describing the relations between all variables simultaneously. This course focusses on supervised learning and has as its goal that the student obtains a thorough technical understanding of selection of supervised machine learning techniques, can choose between them sensibly, can implement the technique in a high level language such as R, python, Julia, or Octave, and can write a report about the technique.

The book of Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman (2001, 1st edition) has been a milestone in connecting statistical ideas into machine learning techniques. Parts of this book will form the basis of this course. A tentative overview of techniques and ideas to be treated are a selection of linear methods for regression, linear methods for classification, basis expansion and regularization, model assessment and selection, classification and regression trees, ensemble learning (random forests, bagging, and bosting), regularized generalized canonical correlation analysis, partial least-squares, and support vector machines.</body>

<body>To understanding the fundamental building blocks of several machine learning methods, being able to choose from them, being able to program these methods, and being able to apply them sensibly.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94856,2020,Supply Chain Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. M Tekin'],,"Inhoud

Supply chains are complex networks of organizations that supply and transform materials, and distribute final products and services to customers. Managing a supply change is a big challenge as well as an opportunity for both manufacturing and service industries. For a well designed and properly managed supply chain, firms must combine internal and external information in a dynamic fashion and focus on models, analytic tools to predict the future and gain a competitive advantage.

This course focuses on models and analytical tools to design and operate an effective supply chain. It adopts modern forecasting and machine learning methods to improve the performance of a supply chain while reducing the total cost. Students will have hands-on experience on real life applications of data analytics (descriptive, predictive, prescriptive) applied to several supply chain management topics such as

column4: value of information and bullwhip effect in supply chains,

column1: R programming language will be widely used for solving the assignments.

This course explores models and effective analytics tools to design a successful supply chain. Demand forecasting and inventory management are two fundamental topics of supply chain analysis. In terms of demand forecasting, students will learn how to accurately predict the number of items to be sold next week/month/year based on a historical sales data. The mathematical and econometrics tools (i.e. time series analysis) will prove useful to forecast future demand. Once demand is estimated accurately, the next step is the inventory management. Here, several replenishment methods will be studied. In the remaining period, other relevant topics of supply chain management such as revenue management will also be discussed. At the end of the course students will

column4: Be able to examine and improve the supply chain operations such as flow of materials through a network of suppliers, manufacturers, distributors and retailers,
Be familiar with managing uncertainty in supply chains,
Understand tradeoffs to manage inventories in real world,
Familiarize themselves with analytical tools and models for effective solutions to problems in managing a supply chain,
Address the analytical challenges arising in supply chains.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94773,2020,Supply Chain Decision Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Tekin', 'dr. S Lemmens']",,"Inhoud

Success in a complex supply chain environment depends on your ability to make good decisions. This requires a systematic, data-driven and fact-based approach to decision-making and problem analysis. The same philosophy is also at the heart of scientific research. This course teaches you a variety of tools for business analytics and optimization modelling. You will explore the research that aims to solve decision problems in the supply chain management. Moreover, this course will prepare you for your thesis project, which starts in January.
Upon completion of this course students are prepared to:

column4: Solve business decision problems via optimization modelling
Implement optimization models and approaches in CPLEX

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94767,2020,Supply Chain Fundamentals,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. Q Kong'],,"Inhoud

The course is a mix of lectures, case studies, and games. The lectures are meant to explain supply chain models and concepts making use of both qualitative and quantitative methods. Qualitative methods involve theoretical frameworks, conceptual analysis, and evaluation of solution strategies whereas quantitative methods involve mathematical analysis, probability theory and basic concepts of microeconomics. Case studies depict a business scenario at a certain existing company
column2: in which complex supply chain management decisions need to be taken. The situation is often partly described from the perspective of one of the key players in the decision–making process
column3: furthermore, a certain degree of urgency is present as well. A teaching case requires very thorough preparation by the participant. Finally, students will be required to play game in a supply chain context, which will involve strategic and operational decisions.

column1: To pass this core course, a participant needs to:

column4: Individual and group assignments (including game performance and reports) (40% of the final grade)
Take a written exam (60% of the final grade).

column1: Supply chain management has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, given the current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. This core course is intended for students with a strong interest in understanding logistics and operations – in either manufacturing or service industries – and the role supply chains and supply chain operations can play in business. The course will be particularly valuable for those who see their careers in operations/supply chain over the coming decade, or who see themselves consulting in operations/supply chain for client businesses. The course objectives are to:

column4: Make you conversant in the language of supply chain management and expand your confidence in these area
Allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations

Analyze the underlying issues and trade-offs between the sourcing of raw materials, the manufacturing, storage, and transportation of products and the services required to fulfill customer expectations and the metrics of the firm
Provide you with quantitative and qualitative tools to identify, analyze and manage supply chain operations and issues
Analyze supply chains and supply chain operations to identify problems and improvement opportunities
Recommend and initiate supply chain improvement actions and projects
Enhance your team working and project management skills

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95351,2020,Supply Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Becker-Peth', 'dr. S Lemmens', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']",,"Inhoud

Companies have over time specialized in a very limited number of business activities which they consider to be their core business. By doing so, they have been able to greatly increase their expertise, innovative capabilities and process efficiency. Companies have subsequently located their operations in regions that are most suitable in terms of natural resources, labor (either cheap or high grade), sales markets etc. As a consequence, a long chain of companies is involved in the manufacturing of products. These companies have limited insight into each other’s operations, and are often dispersed around the world. Such a situation requires that the chain of companies is effectively managed otherwise processes would falter, customers would have to be disappointed, and costs would surge. Therefore, supply chain management is vital to companies that operate in such chains. Proper planning and managing of the supply chain can make the difference between a successful business and an outright failure.

Progress in information technology has contributed to both the increasing need and opportunities for improved supply chain management. With IT, companies in a supply chain can be connected in real-time, which allows for efficient and effective sharing of information.

The course program presents cases of real-world situations calling for appropriate state-of-the-art models and solution methods for the design, planning, control and improvement of supply chain operations.
The course Supply Chain Management builds on the knowledge obtained in the course Operations Management offered in Bachelor 1.

In this course students are not only encouraged to acquire the necessary knowledge, but also to develop a critical attitude to the position of firms in relation to various strategic and operational choices related to the supply chain.
<li>make you conversant in the language of supply chain management
<li>allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations
<li>enhance your critical thinking, not only in the area supply chain management but also as a future general manager
• provide you with qualitative and quantitative tools to identify, analyze, and manage basic supply chain management issues.
At the end of the course the student should be able to:
<li>identify and use the main concepts and terminology in the domain of supply chain management
<li>select and use the appropriate instruments and tools to construct a supply chain management solution for a given situation
<li>identify and describe the needed design features of the supply chain
<li>recognize and use the different inventory replenishment strategies to control inventory levels
<li>clarify and leverage the value of information sharing as assisted by information technology for the integrated supply chain
<li>describe and choose the correct purchasing and sourcing strategy dependent on the features of a supply chain
<li>design the physical distribution in a supply chain and adopt the transportation accordingly
<li>identify the different (strategic) constructs for parties of the supply chain to collaborate, and to discuss and mitigate the accompanying risks
• analyse cases of real world situations and develop suitable supply chain management solutions.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94498,2020,Supply Chain Simulation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. ME Schmidt', 'JMDL Hartleb, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Modern supply chain management involves decision making in uncertain, dynamic, and complex environments. This course focusses on the use of simulation techniques to make better supply chain decisions under such conditions. For that purpose, the course combines relevant theoretical knowledge with immediate application of simulation techniques on computer-based tools. In particular, we use Monte Carlo simulations, discrete event simulations, and system dynamics approaches. In all cases, real-life supply chains are represented in computer models. These models serve as a safe playground to study and evaluate supply chain decision making. We gain essential knowledge to improve supply chain performance.

The theoretical foundations for the course are provided in the weekly lectures. Most of the learning, however, happens while you work hands-on on the weekly (individual) assignments, and on the longer group assignment that spans the whole duration of the course. During the weekly workshops, you can get support from teaching staff while getting started on the individual assignment. During the lab session later in the week, you have the chance to ask questions arising while continuing the assignments at home.</body>
In this course, you learn how to build, interpret, and use simulation models to analyze processes and to support decision making.
After completing this course, you will be able to

column4: Understand and apply the key concepts of Monte Carlo simulations, discrete event simulations, as well as system dynamics
Build and verify simulation models in Arena and Excel
Analyze and prepare input data for use in a simulation model
Run experiments with a simulation model, and draw conclusions on the process modelled
Understand the concept of decision making under uncertainty
Gain insight into how the quality of a solution is affected by unknown factors and by an unknown future

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94502,2020,Supply chain forecasting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J van Dalen', 'dr. R Kuik']",,"Inhoud

The forecasting of product demand, new product success, risk events, prices, costs and capacity dynamics is an important activity in every day decision making in companies throughout the supply chain. It directly affects inventory management, procurement and production decisions, logistics resources and financial planning, and thus has a strong impact on the performance of individual companies, as well as that of a supply chain as a whole. The Supply Chain Forecasting elective is about acquiring a robust understanding of common and advanced forecasting methods used in practice, and about training programming skills to apply these methods in practical situations.&nbsp
In particular, the following topics will be covered:

column4: Machine learning techniques, e.g., decision trees, random forests, gradient boosting
Forecasting intermittent demand, and the relation between forecasting and inventory management
Judgmental forecasting, and the influence of judgmental adjustments on forecast performance&nbsp

column1: The learning objectives of this course are:

column4: Understand and apply the common forecasting and analytics methods used in business, both in terms of assumptions and operation&nbsp
Ability to apply forecasting and analytics in programming, involving data processing, selection and application of relevant analytical functions, collect and present the outcomes of analyses
column5: solve non-trivial statistical problems using a programming language and environment, e.g., R and RStudio

column4: Demonstrate the ability to effectively communicate ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders. &nbsp
Critically reflect on ethical ramifications of data collection, team work and proposed implementations of analytical findings.

Bedrijven zijn zich in toenemende mate gaan specialiseren op een beperkt aantal kernactiviteiten (de zogenaamde ‘core business’). Door deze specialisatie zijn bedrijven in staat om op hun deelgebied veel kennis op te bouwen, innovatieve producten te ontwikkelen en efficiënt te werken. Bedrijven vestigen zich op locaties die voor hun specialisme het meest geschikt zijn. Dit kan zijn vanwege de beschikbaarheid van grondstoffen, goedkope of juist hoogwaardige arbeidskrachten, belangrijke afzetmarkten, etc. Als gevolg van deze specialisatie is een lange keten van bedrijven betrokken bij de fabricage van een eindproduct. Bedrijven die vaak een beperkt inzicht hebben in elkaars activiteiten en die verspreid over de hele wereld kunnen zitten. Een dergelijke situatie vereist dat de keten van bedrijven goed gemanaged wordt omdat anders de processen vastlopen, klanten teleurgesteld moeten worden en kosten hoog oplopen. Supply chain management is daarom van cruciaal belang voor bedrijven die zich in dergelijke ketens bevinden. Het plannen en managen van de supply chain kan het verschil maken tussen een succesvol bedrijf en een complete mislukking.

De vooruitgang in informatietechnologie heeft bijgedragen aan zowel de stijgende behoefte als aan de toenemende kansen voor een verbeterd supply chain management. Met behulp van IT kunnen bedrijven hun supply chain koppelen aan real-time informatie en kan op een effectieve en efficiënte manier kennis gedeeld worden.
In dit vak worden verscheidene bedrijfscases gepresenteerd die vragen om state-of-the-art modellen en oplossingsmethoden voor ontwerp, planning, beheersing en verbetering van supply chains.

Dit vak moedigt studenten aan niet alleen de vereiste kennis te vergaren, maar ook om een kritische houding te verwerven ten aanzien van de positie van bedrijven in relatie tot de verschillende strategische en operationele keuzes gerelateerd aan de supply chain.
Het vak streeft er naar om:
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de student de taal van supply chain management te laten begrijpen en gebruiken
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de student inzicht te geven in de rol die supply chain management speelt in de bedrijfsstrategie en de prestaties van de organisatie
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de student kritisch te laten kijken en denken over zowel supply chain management als andere aspecten van het managen van een organisatie
• de student te voorzien van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve tools om hem in staat te stellen eenvoudige supply chain management vraagstukken te identificeren, analyseren en op te lossen.
Aan het eind van het vak moeten de studenten in staat zijn om:
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de belangrijkste concepten en terminologie uit het supply chain management vakgebied te benoemen en te gebruiken
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de juiste instrumenten en methoden te kiezen en te gebruiken om een supply chain management oplossing te genereren voor een bepaald probleem
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de ontwerpkenmerken van de supply chain te benoemen en uit te leggen
• de verschillende voorspellingsmethoden in supply chain management toe te passen
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de verschillende voorraadbestelstrategieën te herkennen en te gebruiken om voorraadniveaus te beheersen
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de waarde van informatiedeling duidelijk te maken en te gebruiken, ondersteund door informatie technologie voor de geïntegreerde supply chain
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de juiste inkoop- en sourcingstrategieën te beschrijven en te kiezen afhankelijk van de kenmerken van een supply chain
<li style=""text-align:justify"">de fysieke distributie in een supply chain in te richten en het transport hierop aan te passen
• de verschillende (strategische) samenwerkingsvormen te benoemen tussen partijen in een supply chain en de bijbehorende risico’s te identificeren en te reduceren
• echte bedrijfscases te analyseren en hiervoor gepaste supply chain oplossingen te ontwikkelen

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101983,2020,Surveillance in Film, TV, and Media Platforms",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AG Fokkema'],,"Inhoud

The course’s primary focus is the representation of surveillance and intelligence on screen (TV, film, and, to some extent, documentary) and in discussion platforms. Surveillance and intelligence, related but distinct concepts, both go back a long way and it is worth exploring the historical dimensions of these concepts. The theoretical literature is mainly concerned with the social, philosophical, and media perspectives on surveillance and intelligence. In the seminar we will see how developments in surveillance techniques give rise to questions about what can be known and at what price. We shall treat SF movies, TV series and documentaries as reflecting contemporary concerns with surveillance. (For instance, but this is just a tentative list: (T)error, Das Leben der Anderen, Homeland, Black Mirror, Minority Report).

column9: Students will have gained insight into course relevant theoretical debates on surveillance and intelligence
Students can compare and contrast the representation of surveillance and intelligence in film, documentary, and TV in an international perspective
Students can relate the relevant theoretical issues to such representations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92265,2020,Surveillance, visibility and reputation",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. D Trottier'],,"Inhoud

<body>The continued growth of social media platforms, mobile devices and related cultural practices has contributed to a dramatic increase in the quantity of information that any individual or organisation can access. Citizens can use this information in an emerging cultural practice known as ‘digital vigilantism’ where they identify offensive behaviour and bring the offender to a kind of ‘online justice’ by making them visible through naming and shaming practices. These practices are manifest in&nbsp
column4: digital and conventional media in multiple ways. For example:

column1: • Citizens can make use of social media platforms (such as Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr) as well as social news sites (such as Reddit or Geenstijl) to shame other individuals, as well as share personal details about the target (‘doxing’).

• Citizens may also turn to online review platforms such as Amazon and Tripadvisor (or make use of review functions in Facebook or Google) to denounce and shame targets (for example, by leaving one-star reviews).
• News media (including broadsheets, tabloids, and online venues such as Huffington Post and BuzzFeed) may also provide coverage of these campaigns, augmenting the visibility of the incident.

These developments demand conceptual and empirical attention from emerging media scholars. Students will develop research questions for a small-scale empirical project addressing (aspects of) one of these focal points. They will make use of qualitative content analyses on a range of media data, including news reports, editorials, and other public data sources.
• State-of the art theory on the topic of surveillance, vigilantism and mediated shaming.
• Common research designs and methods to examine online denunciations.
• Design and execute a small scale empirical study on the topic of digital vigilantism.
• Report on their preliminary and conclusive research findings in oral and written form.

• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research, with an emphasis on challenges and oppertunities associated with research on and through digital media platforms.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94734,2020,Sustainability Grand Challenges,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. SA Koolen - Maas'],,"Inhoud

This course focuses on the sustainability grand challenges of our times. Sustainability grand challenges can refer to environmental or ecological problems as well as social problems. Examples include climate change, land degradation and natural disasters or global displacement, poverty and inequality. Grand challenges are global problems that require combined efforts and new innovative approaches to better understand, harness, and tackle them.

In this course, you will collaborate to analyze a sustainability grand challenge and formulate ‘solutions’ by engaging multiple partners and by thinking out-of-the-box. Specifically, you work together to create a novel and (commercially) viable solution to a real-world grand challenge. The main learning goal of this course is to understand and harness a grand challenge.

You will work individually as well as in teams and under significant time pressures to analyze the grand challenge and jointly formulate a credible and feasible ‘solution’. You will individually demonstrate your understanding of the grand challenge with an individual essay and by reviewing one of your peers, and jointly develop and assess a solution in a group report. You will present the solution in the group report to a multi-stakeholder jury at the end of the course. Your groups will need to apply your learning of structuring and delivery of a message in time-restricted and context-sensitive ‘pitching’ format for this presentation.
After completing this course, students are able to:
• Evaluate the sustainability grand challenge using different theoretical frameworks on wicked problems, temporality and scale
• Provide feedback on a peer’s evaluation of the sustainability grand challenge
• Jointly analyze the stakeholders related to the sustainability grand challenge
• Jointly develop a solution to harness the sustainability grand challenge
• Jointly reflect on the viability of the developed solution
• Jointly deliver a convincing pitch suitable for the boardroom.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94730,2020,Sustainability Leadership and Planetary Boundaries,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. SP Kennedy'],,"Inhoud

Our world is facing severe global social and environmental challenges. Human population is growing, while the resource base it relies on for wellbeing continues to decline. We have surpassed the ecological thresholds of some of the planetary boundaries that govern a safe space for humanity, while others are being encroached with short windows of opportunity for solutions. Basic needs of many of the world’s people remain unmet, while inequality has grown to the extent that the world’s richest 62 people are worth more than the poorest 50% of the world’s global population.

Sustainability has now long been a boardroom agenda, yet our ecological systems continue to degrade and many social issues remain unresolved. The reality check for business leadership is that nine billion people simply cannot live well in this world if companies do not start finding new solutions to co-create a safe operating space for humanity. In this course we consider how business leaders are taking this challenge seriously.

The goal of this course is to broaden participants’ understanding of sustainability, allowing for a holistic recognition of the interconnectivity of issues and their impacts on the future of business. Participants will learn the basics concepts of corporate sustainability and the meaning of ‘true corporate sustainability’ from a holistic and embedded perspective. The course engages with how and why companies form sustainability strategies and considers how an embedded perspective can be achieved through tools such as the planetary boundaries framework. Participants will be immersed in how strategies may be implemented through a range of the contemporary advancements in sustainability leadership such as sustainable business models, integrated reporting and the circular economy.
Students should attend and actively participate in the classes. Students are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with group exercises.
After following this course, the student is able to:
• Explain business sustainability from a holistic and embedded perspective.
• Analyse how and why sustainability challenges occur within social-ecological systems.
• Explain how firms can use systems and resilience thinking to effectively change how socialecological systems behave.
• Apply systems thinking to create business models for sustainability.
• Evaluate organizational responses to sustainability challenges from a systems perspective.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94732,2020,Sustainability and Behavorial Ethics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MJJ Wubben', 'LDM De Schutter, MSc']",,"Inhoud

With the global population growing to 9.7 billion people, the World Business Council for Sustainable Development forecasts that if organizations do not drastically revise their way of doing business, humanity will be consuming the ecological resources of 2.3 earths in 2050. To avert the disaster that would ensue, organizations need to foster sustainable development by helping to meet the needs of the present generation without compromising the needs of future generations. This requires a focus not only on economic, but also on environmental and social performance. &nbsp

Such a focus is not self-evident. Think of high-profile scandals such as the Enron, Worldcom, and Parmalat debacles, not to mention the global banking crisis. The economic, social, and environmental consequences of such drastic, moral transgressions may be so profound that they potentially nullify any sustainable development. Yet even for the many organizational members—CEOs and employees alike—that do embrace sustainability, dilemmas and challenges arise: When should environmental outcomes prevail over social outcomes? How much should we rely on technological solutions? How can we and our stakeholders bridge the gap between good intentions and good behavior? These issues show that sustainability and ethics go hand in hand, and that both present and future business leaders need to embody both.&nbsp

This course offers a broad, psychological and philosophical perspective on sustainable, moral behaviour in business. How can such behaviour be encouraged in employees, in CEOs, in organizations as a whole, and in their stakeholders? Conversely, how can unsustainable, immoral behaviour be averted? Such questions will be discussed in the context of, among others, normative stakeholder theory, greenwashing, green consumerism, social dilemmas, environmental ethics, and moral development and sustainable values in individuals and organizations.

This course emphasizes linking theory, research and practice, and therefore so do the course assignments. As a first assignment, you and your research team will therefore either (a) carry out a quantitative, applied research project on a topic relevant to sustainability and ethics, or (b) conduct research using CSR-reporting from companies either to identify and provide solutions for moral challenges that these companies are facing or to evaluate the fairness of the criteria used by an NGO that ranks brands on sustainability (depending on whether collaboration with this NGO remains possible). Both assignments will allow you to further apply theory and literature on sustainability and ethics, as well as to subject your own ideas to (empirical) scrutiny, and to communicate your findings concisely, accurately, clearly and straightforwardly in a paper of 2500 words maximum. You and your team will also present your research to your fellow students, allowing you to further practice communicating your ideas.

The second assignment consists of an individual 1000-word essay where you will reflect on material from at least two different lectures. This gives you the opportunity to creatively process the course material. Perhaps you see previously unimagined potential in some of the theories discussed in the lectures, allowing you to propose brand new applications for sustainable development in business. Perhaps you see ways to improve existing theories and make them more relevant to practice. Or perhaps you are skeptical of certain theories, the link between theory and practice, or the value of the empirical research discussed in the lectures.&nbsp
This course consists of six lectures, two consultation sessions, and one presentation session. Active participation during the lectures may count toward one’s final grade.</body>

column4: To understand the ways in which sustainability and morality are intertwined.
To understand what drives sustainable, moral behaviour in employees, in CEOs, and in organizations as a whole.
To become more self-aware of one’s moral development and sustainable values.&nbsp
To translate empirical research and theory on sustainability and business ethics into real-world interventions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93406,2020,Sustainability and Innovation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. AS Bhaskarabhatla', 'dr. B Hoogendoorn', 'dr. J Garst, MSc', 'dr. SJA Hessels']",,"Inhoud

We are being confronted with significant challenges and opportunities from climate change, biodiversity loss, affordable energy and social and economic inequality. Innovation is fundamental in the transformation towards more sustainable markets and society. In this course you will be provided with theory, concepts and methods from among others innovation economics, entrepreneurship, and environmental economics literature in order to critically assess the role of business and her stakeholders (e.g. government, customers, and communities). We will explore the (im)possibilities of innovating in the context of sustainability in terms of market failures, overcoming market barrieres, deteminants of eco-innovations and the role of public policies. Insights will be applied to specific sectors such as clean energy sector.
Some of the topics covered have been changed:

'Industry transformation and diffusion of innovation', 'Activism, collective action, and cooperation', and 'Public policy and innovation for sustainability' have been replaced by three new topics 'Social and sustainable entrepreneurship', 'Strategies at the bottom of the pyramid', and 'Cooperation and stakeholders'.&nbsp
Additionally, given current Covid circumstances the didactics of the course have been adapted to fit an online format.

Finally, the content of the assignment is more or less the same (some improvements have been made to make the assignment align better with the articles discussed in the 'Systems of Innovation' lecture) however, more options to receive feedback have been created by the introduction of online office hours to discuss the assignment.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94998,2020,Sustainability in the visual arts and crafts,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AMC Brandellero', 'U Hahn, MSc']",,"Inhoud

This course provides an introduction to and application of key concepts and developments in thinking about sustainability in contemporary societies and cities, covering environmental, social and economic dimensions. From the early conceptualizations of sustainable development to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, from the Anthropocene to the climate crisis, from the doughnut and circular economy to green growth and greenwashing – we will start by reviewing and critically assessing the contribution of different concepts to contemporary societal challenges. Then we will apply these concepts to an exploration of sustainable practices in the fields of contemporary visual arts and crafts, mapping out key developments in production, consumption and communication. We will critically reflect on the potential of small-scale urban making and crafts to offer solutions for sustainable forms of production and consumption practices. Moreover, we will appraise the role the visual arts can play in enhancing in communication and activism in support of more sustainable societies and cities. By the end of this course, students will have the ability to reproduce and critically discuss some of the most influential concepts and approaches to sustainable development in contemporary visual arts and crafts.

This course offers an introduction to notions and debates around sustainability in contemporary societies and applies these notions to an exploration of sustainable practices in crafts and the visual arts. By the end of this course, students will have the ability to:
·Recognize and explain central concepts and debates in contemporary theoretical and policy approaches to sustainability
·Analyse key sustainability trends in the production, consumption and communication practices, notably in the fields of the visual arts and crafts
·Critically assess sustainability concepts and apply them to case studies in the fields of contemporary visual arts and crafts.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94673,2020,Sustainable Finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. D Schoenmaker'],,"Inhoud

This course provides insight in the sustainability challenges and the link to finance. The main task of the financial system is to allocate funding to its most productive use. Traditional finance focuses on financial return and regards the financial sector as separate from the society of which it is part and the environment in which it is embedded. By contrast, sustainable finance considers financial, social, and environmental returns in combination and shows how finance can accelerate the transition to a low-carbon, inclusive economy.

The course reviews evidence that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors matter and explains in detail how to incorporate these in company business models and strategies, equity investing, bond investing, and bank lending. The course examines the financial instruments and techniques that can be applied in the context of evolving climate policies (and other sustainability policies). The tools will be applied in a group assignment on the valuation of a company based on ESG factors.</body>

Students will learn to critically review the externalities embedded in sustainability challenges, to link climate change science with the evolution of financial markets, and to identify the sustainability risks and opportunities for financial professionals. In terms of applications, students will gain knowledge of the main metrics and financial instruments related to sustainability, and of the techniques to measure and manage the exposure of investment and lending portfolios.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94508,2020,Sustainable Strategies,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. FH Wijen'],,"Inhoud

Corporate sustainability, inclusive business, corporate (social) responsibility, and shared value creation have been widely embraced by a wide variety of firms. These buzz words basically refer to a firm’s pursuit of social and ecological objectives in addition to the classic economic goals. But what does a strategy to achieve corporate sustainability really look like?

Building on Hambrick and Fredrickson’s (Academy of Management Executive, 2005) well-known article “Are you sure you have a strategy?,” five components of a sustainable strategy will be identified: a sustainability logic (why to go for sustainable business?), sustainability differentiators (how to make a sustainability-related difference?), sustainability vehicles (how to engage a variety of stakeholders?), arenas of sustainable business (in what sustainability markets?), and staging of a sustainable strategy (how to unfold a sustainable strategy over time?).

You will first discover state-of-the-art literature at the interface of corporate strategy and corporate sustainability. Each of the five academic sessions will cover one core strategy component. You will study several relevant articles and make an individual assignment prior to the session. During the classes we will discuss strengths and limitations of the readings, relate each component to other strategy elements, and apply the topic to actual business practices.

Next to the classroom setting, you will conduct fieldwork in a group of students. You will observe a concrete firm that has recently implemented a sustainable strategy. In particular, you will identify a concrete (successful or failed) project—the environmental certification of a particular product, the internationalization of a ‘sustainable product’, development of inclusive business, etc.—and analyze this project using conceptual insights from the academic literature. Drawing on interviews and secondary data, you will comprehensively grasp the essence and details of the project, critically analyze the strengths and limitations of the adopted strategy, and offer constructive suggestions to the focal company to improve their practices. Every group will present the analysis and suggestions during the sixth and final session of the course.
• To gain an in-depth theoretical understanding of the components and interrelations of economically, environmentally, and socially sustainable strategies
• To critically evaluate and compare different theories on sustainable strategies
• To chart the ‘real-life’ practices of sustainable business opportunities and threats
• To apply theoretical insights to the actual setting of a firm pursuing a sustainable strategy
• To develop the skills to analyze all factors and actors relevant to an actual sustainable business project

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94480,2020,Sustainable business models,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. RJM van Tulder', 'R Reshef, MA']",,"Inhoud

Corporate leaders from smaller as well as larger companies, as start-ups as well as big corporates, are nowadays searching for new and more innovative value propositions that can be linked to more future looking and crisis resilient business models. Partly the search is for rejuvenating existing business models, but increasingly the business models introduced are a response to a society that is considered non-sustainable. Enter: the search for sustainable business models. In the literature this tendency is also referred to as ‘shared value creation’, ‘social innovation’ or ‘business model innovation’. Many synonyms are introduced for this ambition. Most of them look at societal issues from a business model (micro level: how to organise it) as well as from a societal level (macro level: what positive consequences will we have from the wide-spread introduction of the business model). &nbsp

column4: Business models: Understanding how company’s ‘value propositions’ are created and implemented in the Netherlands and around the world
column5: we will use various versions and elaborations of the business model CANVAS as red threat for the whole course and for structured conversations.

column4: Wicked problems: Looking at new business models and the way they can create value and/or solve ‘ wicked’ &nbsp
column5: societal problems in general and the sustainable development goals in specific

column4: Context: Considering the extent to which business models can become sustainable in varying contexts: international (the influence of country and regulation), per sector, per issue that companies are confronted with

Critical: Understanding the pros and cons of a variety of new economic models, that are related to new business models: circular economy, the we/shared-economy, the upcoming relevance of (energy) cooperatives
Understanding what the start-up conditions for new and innovative business models are: such as for instance ‘ social enterprise’ and their challenge to get out of the ‘valley of death’
Incumbents and innovation: Understanding what business model innovation looks like from the perspective of ‘incumbents’ &nbsp
column5: (firms that have already a leading position in a market)

column4: New institutional and organizational forms: studying partnerships as part of sustainable business model innovation around the world
column5: from the perspective of companies, NGOs and governments

column4: Sharing: understanding what the business case for ‘shared value creation’ could look like for firms and value chains
column5: how the micro-level of a firm (input dimension of sustainability) can be linked to the macro-level of society (output/outcome dimension of sustainability)

column4: Leadership and motivation: what distinguishes a sustainable leader from a non-sustainable leader? If so desired: defining your own leadership potential and checking how leadership is needed for business model innovation (use the leadership profiler)
Support in your Master thesis effort (provided you write a master thesis that is linked to the sustainable business models theme)
column5: this elective will directly support your master thesis ambitions by linking theory to practice (and hopefully also practical applications)

column1: Music moves us physically and emotionally. Even when we don't move, brain areas related to movement are active when we hear music. Yet traditionally, music has by and large been studied from written scores, which can tell us many things. Scores do not, however, tell us how that music actually sounds or makes us feel. Moreover, it lacks the second most important aspect of music: movement. In recent years, developing technologies and blurring borders between scientific fields have paved the way for studying music from the perspective of human movement. Embodied Music Cognition is an exciting young field in musicology, which has as its core premise that movement in all its facets provides a unique window into musical and human behaviour. This course introduces students to many facets of the field, including the origins and purpose(s) of music, neuroscience, digital audio and emotions, and offers 4 weeks of intensive hands-on experience with students running, analysing and writing up their own music research project.

After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/91808,2020,Talent Acquisition,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. HMS Dietz', 'S Hofmeijer']",,"Inhoud

Ask any business leader to mention the most important drivers for his/her success and you’ll find that “my ability to hire the best people in my teams” is one of them. With the above in mind these 4 observations are striking: (a) in business schools, there is zero to none academic training in “hiring people”, (b) almost no companies train their managers profoundly on this skill, (c) Tasks around “hiring people”, like job interviews, make up for a large part of a business leader’s day to day agenda, especially in more senior career stages, and (d) the academic state-of-the art knowledge on what is good practice has multiple extreme gaps with what happens in everyday business life. For instance, many organizations still base selection decisions on invalid and unreliable selection methods, thus making a bad-informed hiring decision.&nbsp

In this course we will take two perspectives to which related learning goals are related. First, you as a hiring manager: boosting your ability to make effective hiring decisions yourself. Second, you as a business leader: enhancing your ability to contribute strategically to the talent-acquisition goals of others in an organization.&nbsp

In order to achieve these goals, this course will provide insights in the fundamentals of the talent acquisition process, how to effectively acquire/match talent to business needs and modern-day talent acquisition/recruitment/selection methods. The course engages students through a combination of lectures, practical case studies, debates, exercises and discussions. &nbsp

column4: Understand the fundamentals of talent acquisition, recruitment and selection methods
Explain the interfaces between talent acquisition and other elements of the organization
Apply the theoretical knowledge to a business case
Be able to critically evaluate business cases.

<body>Omwille van de coronamaatregelen zullen er dit jaar minder fysieke begeleidingsmomenten zijn, en wordt het bezoek aan het ministerie van financiën waarschijnlijk geannuleerd. We beperken ons dit jaar tot econometrische opdrachten.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94467,2020,Taxation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Kohlhase'],,"Inhoud

Taxes affect many business decisions, such as: where to invest, what organizational form to choose, how to finance a business, when and where to recognize revenues and expenses. This is an introductory course providing you with an overview of what taxes exist, to which natural or legal persons they apply, how taxation affects business decisions, and what the fundamentals of domestic and international taxation are.

The course combines financial accounting, tax accounting, and investment principles to answer the question: How do I take tax-optimal business decisions? This knowledge is complemented by information about recent political developments in the area of taxation. The content from the lecture is applied and deepened during workshops. Guest lectures provide additional insights from practice.

The fundamentals in domestic and international taxation form basic knowledge of auditors, tax advisors, and practitioners in the accounting or tax departments of multinationals. Thus, the course is of interest to those contemplating careers in accounting, consulting, and corporate finance.</body>
On completion of this course, students should be able to:

column4: Define different taxes levied by governments
Solve tasks that include taxes in financial planning
Analyze the impact of taxation on organizational form choices
Evaluate when business profits and when shareholder level profits are taxed
Evaluate double tax agreements and multilateral agreements in the area of international taxation
Evaluate measures to curb tax avoidance
Create recommendations for business decisions including taxes and present them in a report.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93591,2020,Taxation of Multinationals,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. DS Schindler'],,Inhoud

In international taxation, the most prominent and hotly debated issue is how to tax multinational companies. In other words, the debate is about how to handle profit-shifting activities by multinationals, or international corporate tax avoidance in more general. Anecdotic evidence shows that large multinational companies such as Google and Apple, but also IKEA manage to avoid almost all tax payments. Even state-owned companies like the Norwegian Equinor (formerly Statoil) use international tax shelters to reduce their global tax payments.

The issue became a major challenge to public policy. Being concerned about losses in tax revenue and an imbalance in the distribution of the tax burden on individuals and firms, the G20 countries and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) started the still ongoing “Base Erosion and Profit Shifting” (BEPS) project in 2012 that in recent years came up with various proposals to regulate firms’ activities and their scope to shift profits. In its 2013-report, the OECD states that “at stake is the integrity of the corporate income tax”.

On the other hand, corporate income taxes are (one of) the biggest cost blocks in corporations, and it appears natural that firms try to reduce costs and respond to tax incentives. Indeed, (some) profit shifting can reduce the distortions created by taxing mobile capital investment and help to implement a beneficial tax differentiation between mobile and immobile tax bases.

Consequently, both profit shifting and its regulation via anti-avoidance rules come with benefits and costs. To be in a position to evaluate the implications of profit shifting, the need and design of regulation, the impact of tax havens, but also to understand the decision making in multinationals and their structure, it is first necessary to have a good understanding of
• how international tax regulation looks like, and
• how multinationals minimize their global tax payments.
Following up on these issues, the course has three parts.
column3: focuses on transfer pricing of intra-firm trade as a tax-avoidance channel (chapter 2).&nbsp
column4: Part 2examines international debt shifting in a tax-efficient capital structure as a tool to save taxes (chapters 3 and 4). Finally,
column6: 3 discusses the institutional design and the effects of the most important anti-avoidance regulation (thin capitalization rules, controlled-foreign-company rules) in chapter 5.

column1: The structure of the course roughly is as follows:
• Introduction, Stylized Facts, and the International Tax System
• Anti-avoidance Regulation: Thin Capitalization Rules, CFC rules

The aim of this course is to provide students with advanced (expert) knowledge on transfer pricing and debt shifting, and a thorough background in how international (corporate) taxation affects decision making in multinational companies. The course analyzes both strategies to optimize global corporate tax payments in multinational companies and their impact on investment decisions. It aims for embedding institutional details of tax systems and anti-avoidance regulation in theoretical models of behavior and for contrasting the theoretical insights with empirical evidence. The course has three parts. In a smaller part 1, transfer pricing of intra-firm trade as a tax-avoidance channel is discussed. A larger part 2 focuses on international debt shifting and adjustments in the firms’ capital structure as a tool to save taxes. Finally, part 3 presents, analyzes, and discusses the two most relevant anti-avoidance rules (thin capitalization and CFC rules).
• have an advanced understanding of the theory behind how international taxation affects firm behavior, how firms set up a tax-efficient financing structure, and how tax planning affects investment.
• are informed about empirical evidence on both multinationals’ tax avoidance and its regulation.
• know the main regulatory framework and institutional setting to limit international tax avoidance (arm’s length principle, thin capitalization rules, controlled-foreign-company rules).
Upon successful completion of the course, the students

<li>acquired an analytical tool set that allows for formally structuring and solving tax-avoidance problems, but also for evaluating the welfare impact of tax havens and the design of regulation.&nbsp
• can outline set-ups for independent empirical studies on profit shifting.
• are able to independently analyze and evaluate the implications of future changes in regulation and the institutional setting.
<li>can apply their knowledge on international tax avoidance and firms’ behavior in an abstract, but still meaningful way.&nbsp
Furthermore, more generally, when having taken and successfully passed the course, the students should
• have advanced expertise on international income shifting by transfer prices and debt.
• be able to evaluate pro and cons of profit shifting and its regulation.
• be in a position to communicate with specialists in both academia and practice about complex issues in international tax avoidance and the BEPS debate.

column3: final exam counts for 100%/85% (value will depend on assignment procedure) of the total score. The three-hour exam consists of short open questions and some standard (simple) derivations and calculations.

column1: It is a closed-book exam, but non-programmable calculators are allowed.&nbsp
At the exam, students should be able to demonstrate a clear comprehension of the materials studied and discussed during the lectures.

Students will be required to make standard/simple mathematical derivations to describe firms’ behavior and identify comparative static effects. Importantly, the economic logic/reasoning/intuition for all results should be given in each question of the exam.
In addition, students should know about important institutional details (and important differences in regulation) and be able to interpret empirical findings.
The course is based in the profile Economic Policy, but open for International Economics and FEI students as well. Furthermore, it shall be a free elective for Finance students.
Lectures, exam, and answering the exam will take place in English.

In this practical, the student becomes familiar with, and learns to use different neuroscientific research techniques that can be used in forensic neuroscience, such as electroencephalography (EEG), (functional) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and transcranial Current Stimulation (tCS). It is important that the student learns that, especially in this target group of forensic patients, neuroscientific research offers starting points for practice (including violence risk assessment and management), and is therefore an evidence-based approach.
In addition, the students will learn to use all this information on neuroscientific research techniques to write a report to the court as expert witness.</body>
During this course, the student learns to:
• Make an informed choice for different neuropsychological or neuroscientific methods to investigate suspects and perpetrators.
• Explain in the role of expert witness on the basis of neuroscientific information why a particular punishment or measure is or is not appropriate for a particular suspect.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/96283,2020,Technology Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CW Hagen', 'prof.dr. DA Stam']",,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/95329,2020,Technology Management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CW Hagen', 'prof.dr. DA Stam']",,"Inhoud

For centuries, technology has been one of the most important pillars of the economy. Both in production-oriented sectors and in service companies, technology plays an important role. Without technological progress, companies will lose their competitive advantage. Managers have to face the question of how to make the most of technology. What technology is available and which technological innovations are developing? What might be the consequences of a technology for a company, a particular sector or society? What is the role of technology in the strategy of a company regarding its product/services, the production process and the core competencies? In short, how can managers recognize relevant technologies and properly implement them in a company? In this course, you will develop a technology strategy for one crucial high-end technology embedded in a core product of a case company by combining technological and business criteria.

The course is about the management of a company’s high-end technology that is embedded in one of the company’s core business or consumer products. The technology is an essential part of the product, but it may become outdated because of the rise of alternative technologies. These emerging technologies have the same functionality as the current technology, but may (in the future) add more value to the company’s core products and its customers. Therefore, the new technological developments need to be considered for sustainable competitiveness. It does not focus on the question of how to meet a short-term demand in the market by means of technology (market pull), but the focus will be on how an upcoming technology can be used in the longer run for redesigning products/services, production processes or core competencies of a company (technology push).

It is not evident that a company should always shift to the (technologically better) alternative. Introducing an emerging technology may have serious effects on the product, the production processes, the company at large, and the business environment. Therefore, managers should carefully evaluate and compare existing and emerging technologies and their effects. Therefore, the main question in this course is: should the company shift to an emerging technology, and if so to which one?

The aim of this course is to write a strategic plan for an existing company with high-tech products that could apply an alternative technology in one of its core products. In order to reach that goal, you have to analyse the company’s current situation (Assignment 0), compare the current technology with the emerging ones (Assignment 1), study the effects of emerging technologies on the company and its environment (Assignment 2), and combine this information into a proposal for a technology strategy (Assignment 3), which has to be summarized and presented during an executive presentation (Presentation).

The course can be related to SDG Goal 9: Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation. Part of assignment 2 and 3 is to consider the (societal) environment while thinking about the implementation of the emerging technologies.
<body>After following this course, the student is able to:
• Manage (ones role in) an interdisciplinary, collaborative group.
• Critically evaluate the impact of a technology on an organisation and its environment
• Communicate a strategic recommendation for a case company regarding their future use of technology
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93453,2020,Technology and Social Change,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. M Wehrle'],,Inhoud

Technology evidently enables us to control, organize and optimize the activities and functions of our everyday lives. However, a classical critique in the Philosophy of Technology is that technology also creates a distance between us (as individuals), and the surrounding world. In this regard, the great developments in technology arguably lead to the illusion that everything around us is controllable, rendering us ‘safe’ at a distance. Other approaches focus instead on the mediating and connecting function of technology, which opens up new ways of experiencing and communicating. Some of the questions that motivate this course are: does technology really help us to disclose the world and connect with others, or rather does it alienate us from nature, others and even ourselves?&nbsp
column3: How is society affected by technology? Are we shaping technology or does technology shape us and our social lives?&nbsp

column1: To tackle these problems, we first have to ask what do we mean when we talk about ‘technology’. This implies a reflection on the development of technology and its changing meaning, function and role within society
column2: from machines of mass production to virtual communication and the digital realm. This course offers an introduction into the different perspectives on how to understand the relationship between technology and the social lifeworld of human beings
column3: to question, how do technological developments and social changes interact?

column1: We will track the parallel changes of technologies and societies by starting with a historical reflection on the concept of technology and its relation to human nature, from Aristotle, to Bacon, Marx, Engels and Heidegger. On this basis, we will analyse influential approaches in Philosophy of Technology and recent STS like ‘technological determinism’ and ‘social constructivism’. Does technology controls and determines us, or do we socially construct technology instead through our specific needs and actions?
With Latour we will then critically question this antagonism, and explore the idea that we are just a tiny part in a broader network of various non-human and human actors.

We will then engage with (post)phenomenological accounts, who also emphasize the interrelation between humans, society and specific technologies. Instead of describing this interrelation objectively as network, they ask to what extent our subjective experience is mediated, extended&nbsp
Finally, we will discuss the political and ethical consequences of our interdependence with technology in focusing on the role of algorithms, digital environments and social media.
<body>- To acquire basic knowledge of the concepts and debates (and their development) of the Philosophy of Technology, as well as, key perspectives in recent Science &amp
- To describe and analyze technological developments with regard to their relation to social changes.
- To compare and contrast the different kinds of scientific reasoning relevant to the Philosophy of Technology and technological sciences.
- To reflect critically on the assumptions, strengths and limitations of the different perspectives and concepts of technology.
- To apply this knowledge and analyze how technology and society mutually shape each other, with specific focus on the role of digital technologies.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/96164,2020,Technology, Media and Identity",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JH Pridmore', 'P Mashigo, MA']",,"Inhoud

<body>The integration of new forms of technology and media into everyday life have begun to alter our sense of who we are and what we are about as human beings. Our sense of self – our identity – has shifted as ubiquitous technology and predictive algorithms become part of our social experiences. This is clearly evident in forms of social media, news and entertainment, but digitalisation has also changed the way we work, the way we shop, the way we date and the way we relate to our families. This course begins to explore these themes, starting with a clearer understanding of how social interaction and relationships produce and affect identity and how technology has become a mediating factor in our identity ‘constructions’. This is an incremental change from previous notions of self that were intimately attached to place, name and status or position. By focusing on media and technology, the course is intended to develop students’ critical self-reflective awareness of identity in the contemporary era and how media and technology affect the current and future shaping of self. The course draws on contemporary theories of identity, but also takes a practical approach by examining several domains in which identity is shaped. These domains take into consideration how technology and media are integrated into family and intimate relationships, workplaces, marketing, politics, entertainment, and news, giving grounding for a deeper understanding and awareness of identity in these contexts.</body>
• the nature of identity theory as a field of social scientific study.
• the basic theories, concepts, and notions of identity and the ‘self’.
• the effects and influences of technology and media on identity.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
• analyse how media and technology intersect with constructions of identity.
• appraise differing technologies and their influence in communication contexts and domains that are part of people’s personal and professional lives.
• Evaluate and reflect on the ways in which ubiquitous technology and predictive technologies will evolve in the future and the implications for people’s future sense of self.
• Present and communicate their findings and viewpoints in writing, oral presentation, and discussion.
• Reflect on how media and technology is influencing their personal life.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92722,2020,Technology, Policy and Society",Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. RFI Moody', 'prof.dr. WE Ebbers']",,"Inhoud
<body>Today’s society is characterized by many as an information society. The industrial society, which was typical for the 19<sup>th</sup>&nbsp
column2: and the first half of the 20<sup>th</sup>&nbsp
column3: century, has transformed because of economic and cultural changes into a society in which information and information dissemination are central. The course technology democracy and society focusses on the role of modern ICT&nbsp
column4: within today’s society and in today’s democracy. The course will elaborate on which societal transformations are set in motion by the use of modern ICT and which consequences these societal transformations can have for the way in which ICT is used and perceived within society. Additionally topics such as chain information between organizations, interplay between technology and democracy and ethical issues will be discussed. In this course the main topics within the public sector related to technology will be addressed, among others, how big and open data influences the policy process, how computerized predictions can impact the way actors make decisions within matters in the public domain such as water management, climate change or safety and security and how this changes the dynamics of power within policy making, also we will address how the role of policy makers and those involved in the public sector changes into an information broker. Subsequently these changes have an effect on society and this effect will also be elaborated on.

column1: De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding / For foreign students, English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials
<body>After having followed the course, students are able to
• Name which patterns and changes form the basis of today's information society
• Explain how dynamics within the policy process within the public sector change as a result of technology and the emergence of an information society and how this reflects on society
• Explain how public organizations and those employed there change as a result of technological change
• Explain how technology is applied in organizations and cooperation between organizations
• Name and reflect on ethical dilemmas regarding the use of technology
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92272,2020,Television Audiences,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. JC van Sterkenburg'],,"Inhoud

<body>Central in this course are research on television audiences and on audience reception. While many studies focus on the content of media, audience receptions of that content have been under-researched. Consequently, conclusions about media impact often remain rather speculative. In this course, we will explore how television audiences interpret and receive popular television genres and ‘texts’. We will pay attention, amongst other things, to the role played by social dimensions like race, ethnicity, gender, (dis)ability, social class, and religion in audience receptions. Television can be considered a powerful source for giving meaning to these social dimensions, while different viewers can negotiate and interpret these meanings in multiple ways.&nbsp
column2: Various forms of qualitative data-collection and data–analysis (e.g. individual interviews, focus groups, construction of topic list) will be discussed in order to prepare students to conduct independent research into television audiences. The assignments give students room to focus on TV genres/formats they are interested in. The various steps in the actual research process will be discussed and related to specific assignments in the course.

column1: <li><span style=""color:#000000"">The interaction between media representations and audience receptions
<li><span style=""color:#000000"">Audience reception research, with a specific focus on popular television genres and social dimensions such as gender, race, ethnicity, religion
• The different components of qualitative audience-related research and how these components relate to each other.
• Conduct qualitative audience research into TV audiences both individually and in teams.
<li><span style=""color:#000000"">Reflect critically on methodological and theoretical articles in the field
Apply practical skills required for qualitative audience research, e.g. drafting a topic list, interviewing, qualitative data-analysis, presenting findings.</body>

Even as mobile internet access continues to expand, television remains the most popular global medium as viewers watched an average of 167 minutes per day in 2019. In light of this continuing popularity, this course explores the complex relations between television and modern societies. This course uses a variety of interdisciplinary paradigms to understand television in its historical and social contexts. Course readings and seminars address three interrelated topics: theoretical approaches to television, the social dynamics of audience reception, and cultural politics of television content.
Students will have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column13: Theoretical approaches and key concepts related to television.
Perspectives on television at the level of industry, audience, and text.
Analyze and explain television in a variety of historical and social contexts.
Reflect critically on the mainstream and academic discourses surrounding television

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94130,2020,Terrorisme, extremisme en radicalisering: Fenomenen en beheersing",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['dr.mr. F Geelhoed', 'prof.dr. RHJM Staring']",,"Inhoud

Dit vak biedt inzicht in de fenomenen terrorisme, extremisme, radicalisering en de aanpak daarvan op internationaal, nationaal en lokaal niveau. Tijdens het eerste deel van het vak komen de fenomenen en hun verschijningsvormen aan bod. Dit deel betreft onderwerpen zoals de definitie en karakteristieken, de crime-terror nexus, radicaliseringsprocessen, verklaringen voor terrorisme en radicalisering, waaronder de aantrekkingskracht van extremistische groepen, de rol van propaganda daarbij en weerbaarheid tegen radicalisering.

In het tweede deel staat de beleidsmatige en juridische aanpak van terrorisme centraal en hun verhouding tot social justice en mensenrechten. Wat voor beleid wordt er internationaal, nationaal en lokaal gevormd om terrorisme en radicalisering tegen te gaan? Wat voor preventieve en repressieve maatregelen kenmerken de beleidsmatige en juridische aanpak in Nederland? Hoe heeft deze aanpak zich ontwikkeld? Hoe staat het met de effectiviteit van de aanpak? En hoe succesvol zijn deradicaliseringsprogramma’s? Hoe verhouden deze praktijken zich tot mensenrechten?
Terugkerende thema’s bij het beantwoorden van die vragen betreffen de dilemma’s die bij beheersing van terrorisme en radicalisering spelen en de mogelijke onbedoelde effecten daarvan.
Interactieve colleges, waarin van studenten wordt verwacht dat zij actief de leerstof verwerken in samenwerking met elkaar en in interactie met de (gast)docent(en).
Op het einde van dit vak dien je in staat te zijn om:
<li>Op genuanceerde wijze de fenomenen terrorisme, extremisme en radicalisering en hun onderlinge samenhang te beschrijven en verklaren
<li>Kennis over deze fenomenen toe te passen op concrete verschijningsvormen, incidenten en daders
<li>Op genuanceerde wijze de relatie tussen de staat en terrorisme en criminaliteit en terrorisme te bespreken

<li>Verbanden te leggen tussen kennis over de fenomenen en de aanpak, onder meer door de implicaties te bespreken die kennis over de fenomenen heeft voor a) de aanpak en b) de mogelijke onbedoelde effecten van die aanpak
• Kritisch te reflecteren op actuele dilemma’s, social justice en de borging van mensenrechten in de counter-terrorismepraktijk.
